loans.name: Cissy's Group

texts.en:
N. Cissy is the leader of Luganda Kulya group in Gayaza. She is a very hard-working lady with a strong drive to succeed. Cissy has a business where she is a nurse operating Peoples Medical Centre in Gayaza for 8 years. She says that so far business is good and she hopes that it will be better with the help of the loans. She offers over-the-counter services as well as giving admission to the sick.

Cissy also offers dental services, a move that has enabled her to put her competitors at bay. Her goal is to expand her business and start x-ray services. She also hopes to start up a whole ale shop so that she can have two businesses to run.

Cissy needs a loan to be able to add to her savings so that she can buy a plot of land and also buy construction materials so as to build a family house. She is a married woman with 2 children aged 10 and 6 years and she cares for 2 dependents also in school. This is Cissy’s 7th loan and at the moment, she is able to make monthly profits of 1,000,000/= and she hopes for that to increase.

loans.use: Buy a plot of land and construction materials for a family house

loans.name: Margaret's Group

texts.en:
M. Margaret is the chairperson of Wofunira group in Zana. She is a 52-year-old and a very hard-working lady with a poultry business in Naziba, Seguku for the past 10 years. Over that time, her farm has expanded and at the moment, she has 2000 layers and 400 broilers and she hopes to increase it further.

Margaret is a widow with 11 children and she cares for 6 dependents including paying their school fees and general upkeep. Margaret needs a loan to be able to buy chicken feed and chicks for farm expansion.

loans.use: Buying chicken feed and chicks for farm expansion

loans.name: Mrs. Kung Nhoem Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Twenty-nine people living in Ta Reab DoU. S. village in Kandal province comprise this village bank loan group, and they will use their loans for various purposes. Mrs. K. N. is the 48-year-old village bank president. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land where she cultivates both rice and vegetables. In her rice cultivation, she has some problems because she does not have rice seed and her field is infertile which affects her crop. In order to deal with these problems, she decided to ask for a loan to buy rice seed, fertilizer, and pesticides to support the rice field. Her husband, Mr. Sao Chhin, is a fisherman. This couple has five children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while the others are enrolled in the local school.

One member in this group has an end-of-term loan and the rest have monthly payment loans. EoT borrowers are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: to buy rice seed, fertilizer, and pesticides to support the rice field

loans.name: Sylivia Nakawooya’S Group

texts.en: Sylvia is the leader of a 4-member group. She is a 24-year-old married woman with two children aged 1 and 3. One of her children goes to school. She resides in and owns a two-room house where she is staying with five people. Sylvia takes care of additional family members. There is electricity and no piped water at her home. The family gets two meals a day. She resides and works in a semi-urban area which is at the outskirts of Kampala. Sylvia stays in Nakulabye and sells passionfruit in Nakulabye market. She incurs extra transport costs going to and from Owino market, one of the busiest markets. Sylvia sells to all categories of people, serving an average of 30 people a day. She works six days a week. Sylvia sells mainly on a retail basis. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and rent for her business premises. She has been in this business for the last 5 years. Sylvia has been with MCDT for over two years and is working on her fourth loan, with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of passionfruit and oranges. Sylvia aspires to grow her business and own a permanent business place.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of passionfruit and qranges

loans.name: Beatrice Nankya' S Group

texts.en:
B. is the leader of a 5-member group. She is a 40 years old, widowed, with six children aged between 10 and 26 years. All her children go to school. She resides and owns a four-roomed house where she is living with three people. B. takes care of her sister. There is electricity and piped water at her home. The family gets three meals a day.

B. resides and works in a semi-urban area which is on the outskirts of Kampala. B. is located in Mulago, running a bar selling crude alcohol in one of Kampala's suburbs. She incurs extra transport costs to and from Kalerwe where she buys her crude alcohol. B. sells to an average of 20 people a day and sells to all categories of people, excluding children. She works six days a week.

B. sells retail only. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and rent for her business premises and home. She has been in this business for the last 10 years. B. has been with MCDT for over three years and is servicing her sixth loan, working with the same group-mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more jerrycans of crude alcohol. B. is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger and owning permanent business premises. .

loans.use: To buy more jerrycans of crude alcohol

loans.name: Mrs. Chandoeun Huorn Village Bank Group

texts.en: The village bank, which consists of fifteen members, is located in Ta Reab Doun S. village in Kandal province, and they plan to use the loan they obtained for different purposes. Mrs. Chandoeun H. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. She is a vegetable seller. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy more vegetables to resell to earn more profits to support her family. Mrs. Chandoeun H. is a 30-year-old widow with three children who are enrolled in the local school.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to resell to earn more profits to support her family

loans.name: Ruth's Group

texts.en:
K. Ruth is 37 years old and married, with 5 children aged 18, 16, 13, 10, and 8, all in school. She has had a salon called "Divine Beauty" salon in Kibuye for 9 years and she is able to make 150,000/= in profit a week and this is due to her good customer care.

Margaret has a plan of starting up a school of beauty. Her biggest challenge is training her workers and then, when they learn, they look for greener pastures. She has been a member of her lending group for 4 years and this time round, she wants to buy more cosmetics in bulk so that she will be able to make more profit and savings for her children’s school fees and general upkeep.

loans.use: Buying more cosmetics for her salon

loans.name: Berna Nalwanga’S Group

texts.en:
Berna is the leader of a 4-member group. She is 37 years old, single, and the mother of one child aged 12. Her child goes to school. She resides in and owns a four-roomed house where she lives with two people. Berna takes care of her sister. There is electricity but no piped water at her home. The family gets two meals a day.

Berna resides and works in a semi-urban area which is on the outskirts of Kampala. Berna is located in Ntinda, running a kiosk frying and selling snacks in one of Kampala suburbs. She doesn’t incur any extra transport costs to and from shopping.

Berna sells to an average of 35 people a day and sells to all categories of people. She works six days a week. Berna sells mainly retail. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and rent for her business premises. She has been in this business for the last 8 years.

Berna has been with MCDT for over three years and is servicing her tenth loan, working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more Irish potatoes, tomatoes, and cooking oil. Berna aspires to se her business grow bigger and to own permanent business premises. .

loans.use: To buy more Irish potatoes and tomatoes

loans.name: Harriet Namugabo ‘Sgroup

texts.en:
Harriet is the leader of a 5-member group. She is 45 years old, married, with four children aged between 24 and 30. All her children go to school. She resides in a four-roomed house where she lives with three people. Harriet takes care of her sister’s children. There is electricity and piped water at her home. The family gets three meals a day.

Harriet resides and works in a semi-urban area which is on the outskirts of Kampala. Harriet is located in Lugala, selling natural medicines in one of Kampala's suburbs. She incurs extra transport costs to and from Kalerwe where she buys her crude medicines.

Harriet sells to an average of 20 people a day and sells to all categories of people, excluding children. She works six days a week. Harriet sells retail only. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and rent for her business premises and home. She has been in this business for the last 10 years.

Harriet has been with MCDT for over three years and is servicing her sixth loan, working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more jerrycans of natural medicines. Harriet aspires to see her business grow bigger and own permanent business premises.

loans.use: To buy more Jerrycans of local /Natural medicines

loans.name: Jethro

texts.en:
Jethro H. is from the municipality of Lopez Jaena, Misamis Occidental. He is 33 years old. Jethro is married and has 1 infant child. To make a living, Jethro owns and operates a sari-sari store (a general store). The main source of income for the business comes from selling rice retail in the local community. Jethro has been engaged in his business for over 1 year and earns approximately 9,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Jethro joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jethro has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC. Jethro is requesting a new loan of 40,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Cheryl

texts.en:
Cheryl L. is from the city of Dapitan. She is 36 years old. Cheryl is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Cheryl owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Cheryl is just starting this business.

In 2007, Cheryl joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cheryl has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in future. Cheryl is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Cheryl from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Caroline Nalubega’Sgroup

texts.en:
Caroline is the leader of a four-member group. She is a 39-year-old single mother of five children aged between 12 and 20 years. All her children go to school. She resides in and owns a one-room house, where she is staying with three people. Caroline doesn’t take care of any additional family members. There is electricity but no piped water at her home. The family gets two meals a day. She resides and works in a semi-urban area in the outskirts of Kampala.

Caroline stays in Lugala and has a stationery shop in Kasubi, one of Kampala's suburbs. She incurs extra transport costs to and from shopping. Caroline sells to an average of 20 people a day and sells to all categories of people. She works six days a week and besides her stationery shop, she sells chapati (a flat bread). 

Caroline sells mainly on a retail basis.She buys stationery from Nkrumah Road in the Kampala city center, where there are wholesale shops. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and rent for her business premises and home. She has been in this business for the last three years. Caroline has been with MCDT for more than two years and is servicing her fourth loan, working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more books, envelopes, duplicating papers and pens. Caroline aspires to see her business grow bigger and to own a permanent business premise.

.

loans.use: To buy more books, envelopes and duplicating papers

loans.name: Cerela

texts.en:
Cerela D. is from the city of Dapitan. She is 57 years old. Cerela is married and has eight adult-aged children. To make a living, Cerela owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector selling home products. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling kitchen supplies and products to local community members. Cerela is just starting this business.

In 2007, Cerela joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cerela successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. Cerela is requesting a new loan of 14,500 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Cerela from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About PMPC

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To open a sari-sari (variety store) and expand her cellphone business

loans.name: Asuncion

texts.en:
Asuncion B. is from the city of Dapitan. She is 39 years old. Asuncion is separated and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Asuncion owns and operates a business venture in the food sector running a food stall. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling pork and beef products commonly known as "longganisa" in the local community. Asuncion has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Asuncion joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Asuncion successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,500 PHP from PMPC. Asuncion is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Asuncion from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional food products to sell

loans.name: Joyce Makandaga ’S Group

texts.en:
Joyce is the leader of a four-member group. She is a 49-year-old single mother of five children aged between 13 and 22 years. All her children go to school. She resides in and rents a one-room house, where she is staying with two people. Joyce takes care of her sister. There is electricity but no piped water at her home. The family gets two meals a day. She resides and works in a semi-urban area in the outskirts of Kampala.

Joyce stays in Mulago Katanga, selling milk in one of Kampala's suburbs She incurs extra transport costs to and from shopping. Joyce sells to an average of 20 people a day and sells to all categories of people. She works seven days a week. Joyce sells mainly on a retail basis. She buys milk from Bwaise, where there is a milk depot. 

Her major monthly expenses include school fees and rent for her business premises and home. She has been in this business for the last 12 years. Joyce has been with MCDT for more than three years and is servicing her tenth loan, working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more jerrycans of milk. Joyce aspires to see her business grow bigger and to own a permanent business premise. 

.

loans.use: To buy more jerrycans of milk

loans.name: Celia

texts.en:
Celia B. is from the city of Dapitan. She is 32 years old. Celia is married and has 10 school-aged children. To make a living, Celia owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Celia has been engaged in her business for more than five years and earns approximately 2,500 Philippine pesos (about $52) a month for these activities.

In 2007, Celia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Celia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Celia is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and for working capital

loans.name: Jenny-Ann

texts.en:
Jenny-ann E. is from the city of Dapitan. She is 28 years old and married with 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Jenny-ann catches and sells wild-caught fish to the local community. Jenny-ann has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month.

Jenny-ann joined PMPC in 2008 to gain access to financial services that would help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jenny-ann has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC which was used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks and nets. Now Jenny-ann is requesting her 3rd loan, in the amount of 5,000 PHP, to repair her fishing boat so she can continue to improve the living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: To repair her fishing boat.

loans.name: Pepe

texts.en:
Pepe E. is from the city of Dipolog. He is 39 years old and married with 3 young children. To make a living, Pepe provides taxi services within the community. He has done so for over 18 years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month.  Pepe is requesting his first PMPC loan, in the amount of 5,000 PHP, to repair a vehicle so he can continue to support his family. 

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: To repair a vehicle for his taxi business.

loans.name: Janet

texts.en: Janet B. sells yams and maize at Atabadze near Elmina. She has a senior high school education.  She is married and has two children. Her husband is self employed. Janet has been selling yams and maize since 1990. She is responsible for paying her children's school fees. Her loan will be used to buy more maize and yams to sell. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to help build a house.

loans.use: To buy more maize and yams to sell.

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en: Cecilia N. is a single parent with two children. She has had no formal education. Cecilia sells frozen fish and meat at Atabadze near Elmina, which she has done since 2006. Cecilia uses her income to pay her children's school fees. She will use the loan to expand her business by buying more fish for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Cecilia intends to educate her children.

loans.use: To buy more fish for resale.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary N. sells cosmetics at Atabadze near Elmina. She has received a junior high school education.  She is married and has two children. Her husband is a trader. Mary has been selling cosmetics since 2000. She is responsible for helping her husband pay the children's school fees. Her loan will be used to buy more cosmetics for resale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to build a house.

loans.use: To buy more cosmetics for resale.

loans.name: Alfred

texts.en: Alfred S. is married with six dependents. He received schooling through junior high school. Alfred sells groceries and wheat bran at Esaman near Elmina, which he has done since 1997. His wife is a trader. Alfred uses his income to pay for school fees and other bills. Alfred will use the loan to purchase more groceries. With the new profits from his expanded business, Alfred plans to educate the children.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace N. sells kenkey (fermented corn dumplings) at Esaman near Elmina. Grace prepares the kenkey from maize and this dish is served with fried fish and pepper sauce. She has received a junior high school education.  She is a single parent and has two children. Grace has been selling kenkey since 2001. She is responsible for paying school fees and other bills. Her loan will be used to buy ingredients for her cooking. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to educate her children.

loans.use: To buy maize and other ingredients for her cooking.

loans.name: Fayez

texts.en: Fayez is a 27-year-old married man with 2 children. He has owned a car repair shop since 2008 and has 8 years of previous experience. Today, Fayez is requesting to borrow $1,200 in order to purchase a specific machine used for the cars maintenance so he can satisfy the demands of his customers and increase his income.

loans.use: To purchase a machine for making auto repairs.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther H. sells drinks and large doughnuts at Atabadze near Elmina. She has received no formal education. She is married and has five dependents.  Her husband is an engineer.  Esther has been selling drinks and dough nuts since 2005. She is responsible for paying school fees and other bills. Her loan will be used to buy more soft drinks and ingredients for the preparation of the doughnuts. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to educate her children.

loans.use: To buy more soft drinks and ingredients for preparing doughnuts

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes O. is a single parent with six dependents. She was educated through junior high school. Agnes sells palm oil and tomatoes and other food supplies at Atabadze near Elmina, which she has done since 1971. She uses her income to pay for household expenses. She will use the loan to expand her business by buying more food supplies for resale.  Agnes plans to invest any new profits back into her business.

loans.use: To buy more food supplies for resale.

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort A. is married and has two children. She has received schooling through senior high school. Comfort sells beans and red-red (a dish made with cowpeas) at Atabadze near Elmina, which she has done since 2004. Her husband is self employed. Comfort uses his income to pay for school fees and other bills. She will use the loan to purchase more beans, plantain and other ingredients for the preparation of food for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Comfort plans to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients for preparing food for resale.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria I. sells gari (fried grated cassava), maize and kenkey (fermented maize dumplings) at Atabadze near Elmina. Victoria has received a senior high school education.  She is a single parent and has six dependents. Victoria has been selling gari, maize and kenkey since 1990. She is responsible for paying housekeeping expenses. Her loan will be used to buy maize and other ingredients for the preparation of the food for resale. She hopes to reinvest the new profits from her business.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for preparing food for resale.

loans.name: Clarita

texts.en:
Clarita is a 47-year-old woman of faith and determination to remove her family from poverty. She is mother of three children, two adults and the youngest age 16.  She is married to 47-year-old Benedicto who is a tricycle driver.  They live in the the busy town of Morong, which is in the Rizal province of the Philippines.

To help achieve her goal to rise above poverty, in 1995 she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and now KIVA partner in the Philippines. Her previous loans have been carefully and wisely invested in her sari-sari store (general store). Also part of her loans were also used as capital for her secondary business raising hogs for sale.  She now requests her 12th loan, in the amount of 45,000 pesos, to use as additional capital for her store. The loan will be used to purchase a refrigerator, sacks of charcoal, cases of soft drinks, and groceries for the store.  The remainder will used as capital for a side business, to resell 25 sacks of rice.

She is optimistic that her business will continue to grow since it is properly managed. And with the profits she receives, she hopes of reaching her dreams to build a grocery store, and send her youngest son to school until college.

loans.use: To buy a refrigerator, sacks of charcoal, cases of soft drinks, and groceries for her store.

loans.name: Farid

texts.en: Farid is a 33-year-old married man. He has been working as an electrician in the sanitary sector since 2003 and has 15 years of previous experience in the field. Today, Farid is requesting to borrow $1,200 to buy an electric compressor for his work in order to increase his income.

loans.use: To buy an electric compressor.

loans.name: Janet

texts.en: Janet A. is married and has one child. She was educated through primary school. Janet sells groceries at Atabadze near Elmina, which she has done for some time now. Her husband is a trader. Janet uses her income to pay for school fees and other bills. She will use the loan to expand her business by purchasing more groceries for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Janet plans to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries for resale.

loans.name: Esi

texts.en: Esi is twenty-seven years old and married with two children who are currently in school. She is a food vendor and sells “waakye”. Waakye is rice cooked with beans enjoyed with stew, macaroni and fish. It is sold in the mornings as breakfast. It is very tasty and satisfying and almost all tribes in Ghana enjoy waakye. Esi wants to use the loan to buy more bags of rice, vegetable oil, beans and macaroni to prepare good ‘waakye’ for her customers. She believes this will provide her with increased income to support her children's education to the university level. Esi would be grateful for your support.

loans.use: To buy more rice, vegetable oil, beans and macaroni

loans.name: Mouhanad

texts.en: Mouhanad is a 31-year-old married man with 2 children. He has been working as a home painter since 2000 and has 14 years of previous experience in this field. Today, Mouhanad is requesting to borrow $ 1,200 to buy new tools to better satisfy the needs of his clients.

loans.use: To buy new tools for his painting business.

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en: Gladys B. is a single parent and has three children. She has received schooling through junior high school. Gladys sells cake and ice 'kenkey' at Atabadze near Elmina, which she has done since 2002. Gladys uses her income to pay for school fees. Gladys will use the loan to purchase 'kenkey' (sour-dough dumpling) and other ingredients to prepare the cake and 'kenkey' for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Gladys plans to educate her children.

loans.use: to purchase kenkey and other ingredients

loans.name: Ernestina

texts.en:
Ernestina S. is married and has 5 dependents. She has received schooling through senior high school. Ernestina sells plastic products and shoes and sandals at Esaman near Elmina, which she has done since 2003. Ernestina uses her income to pay bills.

Ernestina will use the loan to expand the business, purchasing more and a greater variety of plastic products for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Ernestina plans to reinvest in her business.

loans.use: purchasing more and a greater variety of plastic products for resale

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary M. sells bags of salt at Ateku near Elmina. Mary has received no formal education. She is married and has no children. Her husband is a farmer.

Mary has been selling bags of salt since 1988. She is responsible for paying for food. Her loan will be used to buy more salt for resale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to build a house.

loans.use: buy more salt for resale

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth E. bakes and sells bread at Ateku near Elmina. Elizabeth has received no formal education.  She is married and has three children. Her husband is a tailor. Elizabeth has been selling bread since 2007. She is responsible for paying school fees. Her loan will be used to buy ingredients to bake the bread for sale. She hopes reinvest the new profits in her business.

loans.use: to buy ingredients to bake the bread for sale

loans.name: Nafisah

texts.en:
Nafisah is the mother of two children who are currently in school. She is a 32-year-old business woman. She sells funeral clothes, lace materials, and textiles and also sells skimmed milk and cocoa powder alongside her cloth business.

For lack of adequate working capital, she is not able to expand the sale of her stock. She believes the loan will enable her to grow her business to the expected level. She wants to use the loan to purchase bulk quantities of funeral clothes, lace materials, and textiles. She hopes to use part of her profit to provide her children with quality education. She would be grateful for your support.

loans.use: To purchase funeral clothes, lace materials, and textiles in bulk.

loans.name: Ragheb

texts.en: Ragheb is a 22-year-old single man living with his parents. He has owned a mini market since 2005 in order to improve his living conditions. Today, Ragheb is requesting to borrow $1,000 to purchase additional merchandise for his store in order to increase his sales and therefore his income.

loans.use: To purchase additional merchandise for his mini market.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes B. is a single parent and has two children. She has received schooling through junior high school. Agnes sells soap at Yesomo near Elmina, which she has done since 2003. Agnes uses her income to pay for housekeeping expenses.

Agnes will use the loan to purchase more ingredients to manufacture soap. With the new profits from her expanded business, Agnes plans to educate her children.

loans.use: to purchase more ingredients to manufacture soap

loans.name: Florencia

texts.en:
Florencia is a 42-year-old mother to Zoe, her 12-year-old boy. She is married to Pepe who is a rickshaw driver and a 41-year-old responsible husband. She lives in the busy town of Teresa, which is in the Rizal province of the Philippines.

Since Florencia was young, she always promised herself that if she had her own family she would do everything possible to rise above poverty.  In 2002, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines in hopes of borrowing capital for her business. Her previous loans have been carefully utilized as capital for her sari-sari store (general store). Also part of her loans were for maintenance on their rickshaw. Together their businesses bring enough earnings to cover their daily needs.

Now Florencia requests her 11th loan, in the amount of 30,000 pesos, to use as additional capital for her store and for the maintenance of her husband's rickshaw. She hopes that with the help of ASHI and KIVA, she can reach her dreams for her child to go to school until college. She also aspires of making her sari-sari store into a grocery store.

loans.use: As additional capital for her store as well as rickshaw maintenance.

loans.name: Leticia

texts.en:
Leticia E. is married and has 5 dependents. She has received schooling through primary education. Leticia sells boiled eggs at Atabadze near Elmina, which she has done since 2008. She carries the eggs on her head and moves from place to place, selling. Her husband is a petty trader.

Leticia uses her income to educate her children. Leticia will use the loan to expand her business by buying more eggs for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Leticia plans to educate her children.

loans.use: to expand her business by buying more eggs for resale

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en: Mohamad is a 30-year-old engaged man living with his parents. He has been working as a gas tanks distributor since 1999 to earn income to help satisfy the needs of the family. Today, Mohamad is requesting to borrow $1,200 to buy more merchandise so he can increase his sales and therefore his income.

loans.use: To buy more gas tanks for his business.

loans.name: Sulemani

texts.en:
Sulemani Y. sells sandals and material at Atabadze near Elmina. Sulemani has received junior high school education. She is married and has three children. Her husband is a petty trader.

Sulemani has been selling sandals and material since 2003. She is responsible for paying school fees and other bills. Her loan will be used to expand her business with more and greater variety of footwear and fabric for resale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to educate her children.

loans.use: expand her business with more and greater variety of footwear and fabric

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary A. sells pastries at Atabadze near Elmina. Mary has received junior high school education. She is married and has three children. Her husband is a petty trader.

Mary has been selling pastries since 2003. She is responsible for paying school fees for her children. Her loan will be used to buy flour and other ingredients for the preparation of the pastries for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to build a house.

loans.use: buy flour and more other ingredients for the preparation of  pastries

loans.name: Farid

texts.en: Farid is a 40-year-old married man living with his wife and two children. He has owned a car electric shop since 1992. Over the years, thanks to his business income, he has been able to meet his children's needs. Today, Farid is requesting to borrow $1,200 to purchase tools for his shop.

loans.use: To purchase tools for his shop.

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en:
Theresa B. is a distributor of dry cell batteries and mosquito repellents by the box at Atabadze near Elmina. Theresa has received junior high school education. She is married and has two children. Her husband is a carpenter.

Theresa has been selling batteries and mosquito repellents since 2002. She is responsible for paying school fees. Her loan will be used to expand her business by buying more batteries and mosquito repellents for resale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to educate her children.

loans.use: buying batteries and mosquito repellents for resale

loans.name: Emilia

texts.en:
Emilia E. has a small bar where she prepares and sells a variety of foods made with pork at Atabadze near Elmina. Emilia has received primary education. She is married and has 5 dependents. Her husband is a carpenter.

Emilia has been selling pork since 2005. She is responsible for paying bills. Her loan will be used to buy foodstuffs and other ingredients for her cooking of goods for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to educate her children.

loans.use: to buy foodstuffs and ingredients for her cooking

loans.name: Philomena

texts.en:
Philomena C. is a hairdresser who owns a very small beauty salon at Esaman near Elmina. Philomena has received junior high school education. She is married and has one child. Her husband is a farmer. Philomena has been doing this since 2001. She is responsible for paying some of the bills for the household.

Her loan will be used to expand her business by purchasing a variety of hair creams, shampoos and other hairdressing products. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to build a house.

loans.use: to expand her business by purchasing variety of hair creams, shampoos, etc.

loans.name: Imane

texts.en: Imane is a 52-year-old married woman who lives with her husband. In 2005, she decided to help her husband support their family by buying accessories and clothes that she could sell in her home. Now, Imane is applying for a $700 loan to buy more merchandise to sell, which will allow her to increase her income and improve her life.

loans.use: to buy merchandise to sell

loans.name: Amale

texts.en: Amale is a 54-year-old widow. After the death of her husband, she decided to support her family by selling goods in her home. Now she is applying for a $700 loan to improve her life by buying more merchandise to sell to her customers.

loans.use: to buy more merchandise to sell to her customers

loans.name: Adjoa

texts.en:
Adjoa E. is married and has 6 dependents. She has received no formal education. Adjoa sells fish at Ankwandah near Elmina, which she has done since 2001. Her husband is a farmer. Adjoa uses her income to pay housekeeping expenses.

Adjoa will use the loan to purchase more fish for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Adjoa plans to build a house.

loans.use: to purchase more fish for resale

loans.name: Mensiwah

texts.en:
Mensiwah A. is married and has three children. She has received schooling through junior high school.

Mensiwah sells fish at Ayensudu near Elmina, which she has done since 2001. Her husband is a mechanic. Mensiwah uses her income to pay bills.

Mensiwah will use the loan to purchase more fish for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Mensiwah plans to reinvest in her business.

loans.use: to purchase more fish for resale

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en: Mohamad is a 33-year-old married man with two children. He has owned a car-repair shop since 2007 and draws customers from his own and neighboring villages. Mohamad is applying for a loan of $1,000 to buy additional supplies for his shop, and to satisfy the needs of his customers.

loans.use: to buy additional supplies for a car-repair shop

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama A. sells maize and plantains at Ayensudu near Elmina. Ama has received no formal education. She is married and has 6 dependents. Her husband is a commercial driver.

Ama has been selling maize and plantains for some time now. She is responsible for paying bills for her household. Her loan will be used to purchase more food supplies to increase her clientele and expand her business. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to educate her children.

loans.use: purchase more food supplies to expand her business

loans.name: Liliane

texts.en: Liliane is 21 years old, engaged and lives with her parents. Earlier this year, she decided to open a clothing store called the "Lily Shop" in order to improve her life and the life of her fiancee. Today, she is seeking to increase her income by applying for a loan of $1,000 to buy additional merchandise to sell.

loans.use: to buy additional merchandise to sell

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary A. has been selling groceries at Atabadi near Elmina since 2007. She is married and has six dependants. Her husband is a teacher. She has received no formal education. Mary uses her income to meet her financial responsibilities. Mary will use this loan to purchase more groceries for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Mary plans to build a house.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries for resale

loans.name: Nehme

texts.en: Nehme is a 36-year-old married woman. She has owned a flower shop called the "Flowers Kingdom" for the past 12 years, and works hard to help her husband support their family. She is applying for a loan of $1,000 to buy new flower stands for her shop and satisfy customer demand.

loans.use: buy new flower stands for her shop

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mercy K. sells bread, oranges, mineral water, etc., at Atabadi near Elmina. Mercy has a senior high school education.  She is married and has three children. Her husband is a farmer. Mercy has been selling bread, oranges and mineral water since 1990. She is responsible for paying her children's school fees. Her loan will be used to buy more bread, oranges and mineral water to increase sales and expand the business. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to build a house.

loans.use: To buy bread, oranges and mineral water to increase sales and expand the business

loans.name: Maroun

texts.en: Maroun is a 54-year-old married man with 2 children. He has owned a music shop since 1996. Over the years, thanks to his business income, he has been able to meet his children's needs. Today, Maroun is requesting to borrow $1,200 to purchase merchandise for his shop and increase his income.

loans.use: to purchase merchandise for his shop

loans.name: Maureen Nakitto’S Group

texts.en:
Maureen is the leader of her 5-member group. She is a 41-year-old married woman with five children ages 5 to 20. All of her children go to school. Maureen also takes care of additional family members. There are a total of 9 people living in the five roomed house she owns. There is electricity but no piped water at her home. The family gets two meals a day. She resides and works in a semi urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala. Maureen stays in Wakaliga and sells foods like samosas (cow peas) pancakes, mandazi and chqapati’s in two schools - one in Wakaliga and one in the Kampala suburbs. She incurs extra transport costs to shop at Owino market, one of the busisest markets in the area. Maureen sells to an average of 50 people a day and sells to all categories of people. She works two days a week. Her major monthly expenses include school fees. She has been in this business for the last 5 years.

Maureen has been with MCDT for over six years and servicing her fourth loan, working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of wheat flour, sugar and cooking oil. Maureen aspires to see her business grow bigger and to buy a permanent business location.

loans.use: to buy more sacks of wheat flour, sugar and cooking oil

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en: Ahmad is a 25-year-old single man living with his parents. In 2005, he decided to open a furniture shop to start a new career. Today, Ahmad is requesting to borrow $1,200 to buy new tools in order to develop his work and increase his income.

loans.use: to buy new tools

loans.name: Youssef

texts.en: Youssef is a 32-year-old single man living with his father. Ha has owned a barber shop named "Prince" since 2006 to improve life conditions for his father. Today, Youssef is requesting to borrow $1,200 to add new decor to his shop in order to attract new clients.

loans.use: add new decor and furnishings

loans.name: Chadi

texts.en: Chadi is a 34-year-old single man living with his parents. He has owned a fishing equipment sales shop since 2000. Today, Chadi is requesting to borrow $1,200 to perform maintenance on his shop and purchase new tools to increase his income.

loans.use: perform maintenance on his shop and purchase new tools

loans.name: Jane Nakawuka's Group

texts.en:
Jane is a leader of 5 members of a group. She is a 36-year-old married woman with five children aged 5 to 18 years. All her children go to school. She resides and owns a five-room house where she is staying with nine people. Jane takes care of additional family members There is electricity and no piped water at her home. 

The family gets two meals a day. She resides and works in a semi urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala. Jane stays in Nakulabye running a pub selling beer and cold drinks in one of the Kampala suburbs. She doesn’t incur any extra transportation costs as she buys from her place of work. Jane sells to an average of 20 people a day and sells to all categories of people excluding children. She works seven days a week. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and rent for both business premises and home. 

She has been in this business for the last 6 years. Jane has been with MCDT for over six years and servicing her twelfth loan, working all this long with the same groupmates. She wants to use this loan to buy more crates of beer and sodas. Jane is aspiring to seeing her business grow bigger and owning a permanent business premise. 

.

loans.use: To buy more crates of beer and soda

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en: Hussein is a 22-year-old single man living with his parents. In 2007, he decided to open a special tobacco shop as his own business. Today, Hussein is requesting to borrow $1,200 to purchase additional merchandise in order to satisfy the needs of his clients.

loans.use: purchase additional merchandise

loans.name: Trabajando Para El Futuro 6 Group

texts.en:
Vicente J. is approaching Esperanza for her fifth loan. She has been previously successful with investing and growing her business with her first four loans. She operates a business out of her home selling desserts and fresh fruit juice. She has used her previous loans to increase her selling volume, and, every time she has increased this volume, she has been able to sell all her products. This is a testament to her entrepreneurial skills and creative business strategies. 

Her ambition in the future is to have her own store to sell these products and to eventually have her own employees. It is a lofty goal considering her current state, but these are the goals that drive our borrowers to work hard every day. One of the reasons Vicente works hard at growing her business is to help her family. She is a single mother raising a nine-year-old girl and a five-year-old boy. She has the highest hopes for her children and wants them to continue their education and go on to college. She hopes to have them become business leaders like their mother, only on a much larger scale.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to increase selling volume of dessert pastries and fresh fruit juices

loans.name: Anis

texts.en: Anis is a 49-year-old single man living with his parents. He has owned a car electricronics/eletrical shop since 1988 to provide, along with his father, for living conditions for the family. After this long experience in the field, Anis is requesting to borrow $800 to renovate his shop in order to attract more clients and increase his income.

loans.use: to renovate his shop

loans.name: Ana

texts.en:
Ana P. of Brgy Zone 4A, Pulupandan, Negros Occidental is a 43 year-old married woman with a 12-year old child.

When Ana joined NWTF-Project Dungganon five years ago, she thought that she'd borrow money to expand her small "sari-sari" store - the Filipino equivalent of a neighborhood convenience store. But later she realized that with access to more capital, she could diversify to other business activities like hog raising and pig fattening to supplement the income she earns from the General Store.

She discovered a knack for this business that she has been at it for the past 4 years now and it helps a lot in answering the needs of her small family. For her 15th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Ana wants to borrow PHP 15,000.00 so that she could purchase more piglets to raise and later sell.

Ana has high hopes for her only child, this is why she is taking every opportunity to earn more to save for her child's education and financial security. 

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: Purchase Piglets to raise and sell

loans.name: Alec

texts.en: Alec is a 34-year-old single man. He has owned a car repair shop since 2000.  Alec is requesting to borrow $1,000 to purchase new tools for his shop so he can satisfy the heavy demands of the market and help increase his income.

loans.use: purchase new tools

loans.name: Resty Nambogoli ’S Group

texts.en:
Resty is a 32 years old, is married and has five children. All her children attend school. She currently owns a two room house and lives with nine other people. Resty also takes care of additional family members. There is electricity and no piped water. The family gets two meals a day. She lives and works in a semi urban area  in the outskirts of Kampala. She runs a shop selling ladies hair extensions and works seven days a week. She uses public  transportation. Resty has an average customer base of ten people a day. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and rent for both business premises and home.  

Resty is a leader of five member group. Resty has been with MCDT for over six years and is servicing her twelfth loan, working with the same group members. She wants to use this loan to buy more hair extensions. Resty is hoping to of see her business expand and aspires to own a permanent business premise. 

.

loans.use: To buy  more ladies hair extensions

loans.name: Stella

texts.en: Stella A. sells koko (porridge) at Atabadi near Elmina. Koko is one of the most popular foods to have at breakfast. She sells this porridge to those who leave their homes early without having breakfast. Stella has received no formal education. She is a single parent with two children. Stella has been selling koko since 1990. She is responsible for paying bills and other expenses. Her loan will be used to buy maize since it is the main ingredient for making koko, as well as other ingredients for the preparation of koko for resale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to educate the children.

loans.use: To buy maize, the main ingredient for making koko (porridge), and other ingredients for the preparation of koko for resale.

loans.name: Emma

texts.en: Emma A. sells onions at Atabadi near Elmina. Emma has a junior high school education. She is married and has two children. Her husband is a commercial driver. Emma has been selling onions since 2002. She is responsible for paying school fees. Her loan will be used to buy more onions for resale to expand the business. She hopes to use the new profits from her business build a house.

loans.use: To buy more onions for resale to expand the business

loans.name: Santiago Apostol Group

texts.es:
Los socios del banco comunal “SANTIAGO APOSTOL”, están situados en el distrito de Santiago en la provincia y departamento del Cusco. 

Nuestros socios alternan sus diferentes actividades tanto del hogar como particulares; con la venta de artesanía, tres socias tienen sus stand en el centro comercial confraternidad, ellas traen mercadería de Bolivia (ropas, juguetes, artefactos, entre otros), otros socios venden libros en el mismo centro comercial, otros tiene su stand de venta de desayunos y 2 restaurantes de dos socios, y 2 socios más venden útiles escolares, una de nuestras   socias está ausente por motivos de salud, su nombre es la Sra. Modesta E., estos socios son gente muy trabajadora y desean seguir adelante y para esto requieren un préstamo para reinvertir en sus diferentes negocios.

Nuestros socios valoran y agradecen el apoyo brindado y el préstamo otorgado mediante este medio, y se comprometen a cumplir con el pago en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
The members of the communal bank, “SANTIAGO APOSTOL”, are located in the district of Santiago in the province and department of Cusco.

Our members alternate their different activities, from housework to specific tasks. With the sale of handicrafts, three members have their stand in the collective shopping center. The women bring merchandise from Bolivia (clothing, games, and gadgets, among other things). At the same shopping center, other members sell books, others have a kiosk for breakfast food, two members run two restaurants, and two more members sell school supplies. One of our members, Sra. Modesta E., is absent from the group for health reasons. These members are very hardworking people and want to keep moving ahead, and for that they require a loan to be able to reinvest in their different businesses.

Our members both value and thank you for your support by providing a loan through this organization. They are committed to repaying this loan within the established time frame.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Merchlewitz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Florence's Group

texts.en:
Florence is 52, married, and has five children. All of her children attend school. She resides and owns a two roomed house where she lives with nine people. Florence takes care of additional family members. There is electricity and no piped water in the house. The family eats two meals a day. Florence runs a restaurant in one of Kampala suburbs. 
Florence has an average customer base of twenty people a day. She works seven days a week and has been in this business for the last six years. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and rent for both the business premises and home. Florence has been with MCDT for over six years and is servicing her twelfth loan, working with the same group members. She will use this loan to buy additional stock items for her restaurant. Florence is hoping her business will expand and aspires to owning a permanent business premise.

loans.use: To stock more food for her resturant

loans.name: Aziza Group

texts.en:
Anjela, 38, is married with four children ages 24, 18, 9 and 6 years. She has been selling second hand clothes since 2000. She works daily from 8 a.m. until 5.30 p.m. She is able to earn a monthly profit of approximately $256. 

This will be Anjela’s fourth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to increase the stock of her business, paid school fees, and has repaid the loans successfully. She hopes that the fourth loan will help to increase business. 
	
Anjela will share this loan with her loan group, Azizi, which totals 15 members. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Anjela is the first person on the left.

loans.use: To increase the stock of second hand clothing for resale

loans.name: Analin

texts.en:
ANALIN A. is 40 years old, single and resides at Prk. Proper South, Brgy. Taloc in the City of Bago, Negros Occidental.

Being single does not mean that Analin is without dependents or family responsibilities. This is why she has always aimed for financial independence for herself. When she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2001, and she started a "sari-sari" or general store, her target was to have a successful business within 2 years - and she achieved this by sheer industriousness.

After two years, she expanded her product offerings from just what her neighbors would need like groceries, baked goodies and the usual grocery and dry goods, to fertilizers and other agricultural needs that farms in the area might require. Now she even sells frozen dressed chicken, school supplies and a variety of other stuff that one might not even find in a local supermarket.

For her 18th loan cycle, Analin wants to borrow PHP 29,500.00 to add to her working capital so that she could buy more stocks for her store and offer an ever wider variety of goods to sell to her loyal customers.

Analin's mission is to achieve financial independence and security for herself now and in the future.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: ADDITIONAL WORKING CAPITAL

loans.name: Apu Curi Group

texts.es:
Los socios son un número de 9 miembros, todos ellos pertenecen al banco comunal “APU CURI”, ubicado en la comunidad de Quiquijana en el distrito de Quispicanchis en la provincia y departamento del Cusco. 

Estos socios alternan sus diferentes actividades tanto del hogar como particular, con la agricultura y la ganadería, también son comerciantes menores, ellos venden lo que sus tierras producen (maíz, alcachofas, papa, habas, trigo, cebada, olluco, entre otras variedades de productos según la época), Nuestros socios también se dedican a otras actividades, como la Sra rosa y su esposo Carlos ambos socios tienen una pequeña tienda de abarrotes en el pueblo, otros socios venden granos de las cosechas que quedan, otos, venden lana de alpaca y todos los socios desean volver a invertir su capital de trabajo en sus negocios ya conocidos. 

Los socios agradecen y valoran el préstamo otorgado mediante este medio, y se comprometen a cumplir con el pago en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
The nine partners belong to “APU CURI,” a community bank located in the Quiquijana in the Quispicanchis district in Cusco. These partners alternate their different activities around the home, working with both agriculture and livestock. They are also small-time vendors, selling what they produce on their land (corn, artichoke, potatoes, beans, wheat, barley, ulluco, and various other products depending on the season). Our partners also dedicate themselves to other activities: Mrs. Rosa and her husband Carlos, have a small store grocery store, others sell the grains that remain from their harvest, and others sell alpaca wool. All the partners want to invest their working capital in their known businesses. The partners appreciate and value the loan granted through these means, and they are committed to complete payment within the established period.

Translated from Spanish by Lydia Brantley, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Anexo Huayna Potosi Group

texts.es:
Once integrants forman la asociación, “Anexo huayna Potosí”, ellas se reúnen en el centro focal Alto Lima ubicado en la ciudad de El Alto. 
Una de las fundadoras  es  Candelaria C., que actualmente es la presidenta del grupo, cuenta que invito a sus amigas, vecinas y familia para formar parte de esta asociación.
Son varias las actividades que tienen este grupo, como ser, costura de chamarras, venta de ropa, carpinteria, elaboración de embutidos, tejidos de chompas a mano, entre otras. Afirman que desean incrementar su capital, adquiriendo mercaderia y/o insumos, tienen la seguridad de obtener mejores ganancias, solo con el fin de ofrecer bienestar a sus familias.
texts.en:
Eleven members make up the “Anexo Huayna Potosí” Association. They meet in the Alto Lima community center located in the city of El Alto.

One of the founders is Candelaria C., who now serves as president. She invited her friends, neighbors and relatives to join this group. The members are involved in various business activities, such as sewing jackets, selling clothes, carpentry, producing sausages, weaving sweaters, etc. They want to increase their capital, purchase goods and supplies, and improve their earnings for the sole purpose of providing for the welfare of their families.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Mallku Irpiri Group

texts.es:
La asociación comunal “Mallku Irpiri” es parte del centro focal German Busch, trabajan  junto  a Pro-Mujer hace un año,  su presidenta es  Rosa M., ella ha formado el grupo en sus inicios con vecinas de su barrio,
Este grupo en su mayoría son comerciantes, es decir se dedican a la venta de mantas, mochilas, chompas, cereales, verduras, muebles, tostado de haba, otras de ellas venden comida y meriendas. Esta asociación desea comprar mercadería o insumos para ampliar sus ventas, de este modo generaran mayores ganancias y por lo tanto mejores ingresos para el bienestar de sus familias.
texts.en:
The community association "Mallku Irpiri" is part of the Germán Busch center and has been working with Pro Mujer for the last year. Its president is Mrs. Rosa M., she formed the group with her neighbors.

The members are mainly traders, that are engaged in the sale of blankets, backpacks, sweaters, cereals, vegetables, furniture, roasted bean and some of them sell food and snacks. This association wishes to purchase goods to increase their sales, and get higher profits and income for the welfare of their families.

Translated from Spanish by Adriana Pierce, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Cheryl

texts.en:
CHERYL G. is 40 years old, married with 4 school-age children and lives in Brgy. Canjusa, Pulupandan Negros Occidental.

Ten years ago, Cheryl started making Ginamos - salted and fermented krill - to sell in the local market. But she found that it was not easy if you don't have sufficient capital. So when she was invited to join NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002, she immediately got her husband's consent to join, and that was how her life changed for the better for her and her family.

Now her 4 children are all going to school, and the income from the ginamos is a big help to her family's financial stability and security. Her current operations nets PHP 7,000 per month.

For her 10th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Cheryl wants to borrow PHP 28,000.00 as additional capital so that she could increase her production capacity and improve her income potential.

What is Ginamos
Ginamos is a generic Hiligaynon (the local dialect in Western Visayas) term for anything that is salted and aged to ferment - in Tagalog it is known as Bagoong. Ginamos can also refer to fermented salted fish, mussels, oysters, etc. but in general, the term Ginamos refers to mashed salted fermented krill - all the others must be qualified - e.g. Ginamos na isda (fermented salted fish) or Ginamos na Tahong (fermented salted mussels).

Ginamos is prepared by mashing sea salt and krill together until the salt is well mixed into the finely ground krill, then it is kept in containers to age until ready. Ginamos in Negros Island is usually moist but firm and sold by the block or smaller bricks. Vendors usually pre-cut the blocks into different sizes to offer the buyers a selection. People usually buy Ginamos either as a flavor enhancer to dishes like Pinakbet (a vegetable stew) or as a dish by itself. When cooked as a dish, it is usually mixed with vinegar and sauteed with lots of garlic and sometimes with fried pork rind, and is served with rice as a meal or with green mangoes as an appetizer. 

Cheryl is shown in the picture cutting up a block of Ginamos to sell on retail.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: additional capital to expand the borrower's business operations

loans.name: Vasiliy

texts.en:
Vasiliy is married with two grown-up children. He sells clothing and women's purses at the central market in Pavlograd city. He has been in this business for about three years. During this time, he has set up a first business location and started a second one. Vasiliy says that being self-employed gives him strong motivation to work hard. He enjoys his business and even has plans to start a third location.

Vasiliy would like to borrow 15,000 UAH to purchase a new collection of women's purses. He hopes to increase sales and invest money back into his business.

loans.use: To purchase women's purses

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
MRS. EMILY Y. is 36 years old, married with 2 school-age children, and lives in Prk. Malipayon, Brgy. Canjusa, in the coastal municipality of Pulupandan, Negros Occidental.

For the past 7 years since she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon, Emily admits that she has learned a lot in how she should manage her business so that it could grow and continue to help support the growing needs of her family of 4.

Emily has a food stall in the local market where she sells Ginamos, a local delicacy, and this earns her on the average PHP 12,000.00 per month.

Because Ginamos has to be aged, and production is dependent on the availability of the krill, Emily needs additional working capital so that she could maintain the ideal volume of Ginamos on stock. She needs to borrow PHP 20,000.00 as additional capital to sustain her expanding business.

Emily is working hard to provide for her her children. She is using the income she earns in this business venture to pay for the tuition fees of her 2 children. 

What is Ginamos?
Ginamos is a generic Hiligaynon (the local dialect in Western Visayas) term for anything that is salted and aged to ferment - in Tagalog it is known as Bagoong. Ginamos can also refer to fermented salted fish, mussels, oysters, etc. but in general, the term Ginamos refers to mashed salted fermented krill - all the others must be qualified - e.g. Ginamos na isda (fermented salted fish) or Ginamos na Tahong (fermented salted mussels).

Ginamos is prepared by mashing sea salt and krill together until the salt is well mixed into the finely ground krill, then it is kept in containers to age until ready. Ginamos in Negros Island is usually moist but firm and sold by the block or smaller bricks. Vendors usually pre-cut the blocks into different sizes to offer the buyers a selection. People usually buy Ginamos either as a flavor enhancer to dishes like Pinakbet (a vegetable stew) or as a dish by itself. When cooked as a dish, it is usually mixed with vinegar and sauteed with lots of garlic and sometimes with fried pork rind, and is served with rice as a meal or with green mangoes as an appetizer.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: ADDITIONAL WORKING CAPITAL

loans.name: 14 De Septiembre Group

texts.es: La asociación comunal “14 de Septiembre”  pertenece al centro Focal Villa Adela, trabajan  junto  a Pro-Mujer hace sietes año. Este grupo en su mayoría son vecinas y amigas, ellas se dedican  a la confección de ropa, por ejemplo algunas confeccionan  polleras y centros, busos deportivos, camisas, tejido de mantas en macramé, otras también venden jugos naturales. Esta asociación desea comprar materia prima ( telas en mayor cantidad) para ampliar sus ventas, de este modo generaran mayores ganancias y por lo tanto mejores ingresos para el bienestar de sus familias.
texts.en:
The community organization "September 14th" belongs to the Focal Villa center, which has worked alongside Pro-Mujer for 7 years. This group is made up mostly of neighbors and friends who work making clothing such as skirts, sports bras, shirts, and woven blankets. Others also sell all-natural juices. This association is looking to buy raw materials (fabrics in greater quantity) in order to expand their sales and in this way generate more profits and better income to provide for the well-being of the members' families.

Translated from Spanish by Cyrus Maher, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fabric

loans.name: Valentina

texts.en:
Valentina is married with two grown-up children. She sells women's clothing. Her monthly income is 5,000 UAH. Valentina has been in this business for six years. She has many repeat clients that come back to purchase new clothing. Valentina always helps her clients by giving good advice.

Valentina would like to borrow 11,750 UAH to increase the clothing assortment. She will spend the extra income to improve her living conditions.

loans.use: To increase the assortment of clothing inventory

loans.name: Women Of Progress Group

texts.es:
El Grupo de Mujeres de Progreso está conformado por mujeres luchadoras, trabajadoras y aplicadas entre estas se encuentra Cruz Mayra P. C., Karla Vanessa T., Xiomara Vilche Gaitán y Martina Concepción V. L.. Este grupo son provenientes de Piedra Menuda una comarca de Nindirí de difícil acceso ya que  el transporte tan solo pasa dos veces al día.

La coordinadora del grupo es Cruz Mayra P. C. de 38 años de edad quien está casada y tiene dos hijos menores de edad uno de ellos tiene 10 años y un bebe de 10 meses. Esta señora hace dos años que comenzó vendiendo maní crudo pero por idea de su esposo e iniciativa propia decidió ornear el maní y ganar más. Actualmente vende maní horneado y huso de res. 

La meta inmediata de  P. es seguir adelante con su negocio y poder aumentar sus ventas sin embargo para ello necesita invertir en la compra de su materia prima que es el maní.

Las otras integrantes del grupo son la señora Xiomara Viche Gaitán de 25 años de edad quien tiene una pequeña pulpería, Karla Vanessa T. de 27 años de edad quien vende ropa, cosméticos y realiza rifas y la señora Martina Concepción Viches de 34 años de edad que también comercializa con ropa. 
 
Este grupo ya tuvo su primer préstamo en Adim lo que les ayudo a incrementar su inventario en productos y obtener mayores ganancias. En la actualidad ellas necesitan de ingresos para adquirir nuevas mercaderías y así  ir creciendo poco a poco sus negocios.
texts.en:
The Women of Progress Group is made up of fighting, hard-working, and industrious women, including Cruz Mayra P. C., Karla Vanessa T., Xiomara Vilche Gaitán and Martina Concepción V. L.. This group comes from Piedra Menuda, an area of Nindirí that is difficult to access because there is only transportation there twice a day. The group leader is Cruz Mayra P. C., who is 38 years old, is married, and has two young children, who are 10 years old and 10 months old. Two years ago, this woman started selling raw peanuts, but based on her husband’s idea and her own initiative, she decided to season the peanuts, and she earned more. At present, she sells baked peanuts and animal bones. P.’s immediate goal is to go forward with her business and be able to increase her sales, but for this, she needs to invest in the purchase of raw materials, such as peanuts. The other members of the group are Mrs. Xiomara Viche Gaitán, who is 25 years old and has a small grocery store; Karla Vanessa T., who is 27 years old and sells clothing, cosmetics, and holds raffles; and Mrs. Martina Concepción Viches, who is 34 years old and sells clothing. This group has already had its first loan with Adim, which helped them increase their inventory of products and have more earnings. At present, they need income to buy more merchandise and, in this way, grow their business little by little.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy peanuts and animal bones

loans.name: El Cielo Group

texts.es:
El grupo el Cielo está conformado por Benicia Victoria Murillo R., Magali M. R. y Katia R. P.; ellas son provenientes de Piedra Menuda una comarca de Nindirí. Esta es una zona rural de difícil acceso ya que  el transporte tan solo pasa dos veces al día. 

Este grupo de mujeres ya  han tenido dos créditos con adim con los cuales lograron incrementar su materia prima y sus clientes es por eso que podemos asegurar que son trabajadoras, emprendedoras, perseverantes y con muchos deseos de superarse.

La coordinadoras del grupo es la señora Benicia Murillo 57 años de edad, ella está casada con don Antonio M. quien es agricultor y con quien tuvo tres hijos. Ellos viven en una pequeña casa prefabricada que cuenta con los servicios necesarios.

Murillo hace dieciocho años decidió tener un pequeño negocio en casa;  ya que necesitaba mayores ingresos y es así que decidió establecer una pulpería que le permitiera atender a su hija que tiene síndrome de Down. 

Con el tiempo su pulpería ha ido creciendo poco a poco actualmente tiene mayor de manda de productos que representa un incremento el volumen de ventas pero para ello necita aumentar su inventario tanto en granos básicos que son maíz, frijol, arroz, trigo, aceite y chiverías entre otros.

Las otras dos integrantes son  Magaly Margarita Mana R. de 25 años de edad es soltera, estudio secundaria y actualmente se dedica a vender cosméticos de marca especialmente de la Avon y Zermat. Asimismo  Katia Lucia R. P. que vende cosméticos también de la marca de la Avon y Zermat. Ella está casada con Fredy M. Murillo  técnico en refrigeradoras y  con quién  vive en la casa de su suegra.  

Todas ellas necesitan contar con una reinversión para sus negocios ya sea en la compra de productos básicos como es el caso de la coordinadora o en la adquisición cosméticos, perfumes y cremas de las otras dos integrantes.
texts.en:
The Sky Group is made up of Benicia Victoria Murillo R., Magali M. R. and Katia R. P.. They are from Piedra Menuda, an area of Nindirí. This is a rural area that is difficult to access because transportation only goes there twice a day. This group of women has already had two loans with Adim, with which they succeeded in increasing their raw materials and their clients. Because of this, they were able to assure that they are hard-working, enterprising, persevering, and have a great desire to overcome. The group leader is Mrs. Benicia Murillo, who is 57 years old and is married to Mr. Antonia M., who is a farmer. They have three children. They live in a small house, which has the necessary amenities. Eighteen years ago, Murillo decided to have a small business in her house because she needed a larger income. As a result, she decided to establish a small grocery store, which would allow her to take care of her daughter, who has Downs Syndrome. Over time, her grocery store has been growing little by little. At present, she has a high demand for her products, which means an increase in the volume of her sales, but to accommodate this, she needs to increase her inventory a lot in basic goods, like corn, beans, rice, wheat, oil, and other things. One of the other two members is Magali Margarita Mana R., who is 25 years old, is married, has completed secondary school, and at present, sells Avon and Zermat brand cosmetics. The other member, Katia Lucia R. P., also sells Avon and Zermat cosmetics. She is married to Fredy M. Murillo, a refrigerator technician. They live in her mother-in-law’s house. All of them need to reinvest in their business, by buying basic products, as in the case of the group leaders, or by buying perfumes and creams, as in the cases of the other two members.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various products, especially basic goods

loans.name: Rebelde Group

texts.es: En el centro focal  Santiago II, cada dos semanas, se reúne la asociación “Rebelde”, está conformado por dieciocho integrantes, demostrando responsabilidad en sus tres años de trabajo junto a Pro-Mujer. Diversos son los negocios de este grupo, tales como: venta de golosinas, elaboración de comida, tejido a mano de mantas y mantillas, pastelería, venta de cosméticos, confección de edredones, entre otros. Ellas desean ampliar su producción, para esto necesitan comprar mercadería y/o materia prima, tienen la seguridad que obtendrán mejores ganancias y por lo tanto mayores ingresos para sus familias.
texts.en:
Every two weeks, in the center of Santiago II, the “Rebel” Association meets. It is made up of 18 members and has demonstrated its responsibility in its three years of working together with Pro-Mujer (Pro-Woman). There are various businesses in this group including candy sales, food preparation, hand-woven blankets and shawls, cake baking, cosmetic sales, and quilt making, amongst others.
