texts.fr: Maty N. est âgée de 44 ans, mariée et mère de 8 enfants. Elle veut ce prêt pour augmenter son capital de commerce de produits cosmétiques. Cette activité lui permet de mieux participer aux dépenses familiales afin d’améliorer leur condition de vie.
texts.en:
Maty N. is 44 years old, married and mother to 8 children. She wants this loan to increase her stock of cosmetics for sale. This business allows her to play a bigger role in family expenses and so improve their quality of life.

Translated from French by Lara Francis, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cosmetics for resale

loans.name: Roberto Jose

texts.es: Roberto Jose de 37 años de edad, es casado, trabaja como contador, ademas es tecnico en reparaciones de computadoras, tiene 2 niños cursando la escuela primaria, su esposa tiene una pequeña tienda de venta de ropa, cosmeticos y otros.  Esta solicitando su 8vo credito para invertirlo en un pequeño negocio de video-juegos que tiene en su casa de habitacion donde obtiene ingresos adicionales para el sustento familiar, comprando nuevos cd de juegos, cambio de algunos equipos y acondicionar y poco mas el local.  El mayor sueño de Roberto es poder darle a su familia las mejores condiciones de vida para que sus hijos puedan crecer en un ambiente feliz y comodo, ademas desea que estos estudien hasta que lleguen a ser profesionales.
texts.en:
Roberto Jose is 37 years old and married with two children in primary school. He is an accountant and computer repairman. His wife has a small store selling clothing, cosmetics and other products. He is asking for his eighth loan to invest in a small video game business in his home where he earns additional funds to support his family by buying and selling new games cds and upgrading equipment and fixing up his shop. His dream is to be able to give his family the best life possible so that his children can grow in a comfortable and happy way and have the education to find professional work.

Translated from Spanish by Patty Harvey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in a video game room.

loans.name: Teresa De Jesus

texts.es: La señora Teresa de Jesús C. C., ella tiene 29 años, es casada y posee un hijo de 5 años de edad. La señora C. C. tiene aproximadamente 5 años de dedicarse a una tienda de artesanías, el cual está ubicado en el mercado de artesanías. Ella inicio hace cinco años, sin embargo con el paso del tiempo le dieron un local y ella decidió mudar su negocio. Ahora cuenta con una gran variedad de clientes que frecuentan su local. A Teresa le gusta mucho su trabajo, pues muchos clientes aprecian su humilde trabajo. El crédito será invertido en la compra de más mercancías, para diversificar más su negocio. Su sueño es llegar a tener un modulo grande en el mercado.
texts.en:
Sra. Teresa de Jesús C. C. is 29 years old, married, and has a 5 year old son. She has a shop located in the handicrafts market. When she started her business 5 years ago, she started selling products from home but then decided to relocate her business. She now has a variety of customers who frequent her store. Teresa enjoys her job, and her customers appreciate her efforts.

Her loan will be used to buy more merchandise and further diversify her business. Her dream is to have a larger vending location in the market.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital

loans.name: Carol

texts.en:
CAROL M. is 34 years old, married with 3 school-age children and is a resident of Irrigation Taloc, Bago City, Negros Occidental.

She showed her business acumen at an early age, and her parents discovered that she could independently handle a business venture even then. When she got married, she decided to set up a traveling sales business. With the help of her husband, she and her crew would move from town to town, set up a tent and display a wide variety of products for sale to the locals during their town's market day. A customer can buy anything from barrettes or hair accessories to brooms and floor mats, flashlights, baseball caps to clothes hangers, and other stuff from Carol's traveling store.

Although this is very hard work, involves long hours and requires a lot of traveling, Carol finds that the financial returns is worth the effort. She has used her previous loans to stock up on the fast moving items in her inventory. And for this 20th loan cycle from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Carol wants to borrow PHP 50,000.00 to again add more items to her very wide variety of product offerings.

Carol is very determined to work hard to provide a good and comfortable living for her family. She is also setting aside some of her profits for the education of her 3 children.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: ADDITIONAL WORKING CAPITAL & INVENTORY

loans.name: Caminando Juntos Group

texts.es:
L. señora Sabina M. emprendedora e ingeniosa tiene 45 años D. edad, conviviente y con  6 hijos.
Viene trabajando con EDAPROSPO – Prosperidad  desD. hace unos días, asume el cargo D. presidenta D. L. alcancía comunal” Caminado Juntos” L. cual esta conformado por  11 socios quienes se dedican a diversas actividades como: venta D. pasteles, venta D. mazamorras, venta D. maní confitado, venta D. desayunos (maca y quinua) en forma ambulante.
Sabina  se dedica a L. venta D. comida ambulatoria  en las afueras D. una fábrica textil desD. hace  6años, el trayecto  para llegar a su punto D. venta dura entre  50 a 60 minutos y lleva aprox. D. 40 a 50 menús diarios, para L. cual algunas veces cuenta con el apoyo D. su hija pero otras veces elL. carga con todo el peso.
Con el préstamo D. S/. 400.00 Nuevos Soles lo invertirá en L. compra D. nuevas ollas  para L.  venta D. su comida, ya que las ollas que utilizan son pequeñas y no abastecen para todos sus clientes.
El anhelo D. Sabina es poder llegar a poner una bodega en su casa ya que esta cansada D. salir a vender todos los días lejos D. su hogar.
texts.en:
Sabina M. is an enterprising and resourceful 45-year-old woman who lives with her 6 children. She has been working with Kiva partner EDAPROSPO – Prosperidad for several years, and holds the office of president of the “Caminando Juntos” communal bank. This group is maD. up of 11 members who make a living as street vendors selling different foods such as cakes, mazamorras [a corn pudding dish], candied peanuts, and breakfasts (consisting of maca [an Andean root vegetable] and quinoa). For 6 years now Sabina has maD. a living selling food from a stand outsiD. a textile factory. The journey from her home to her stand takes between 50 and 60 minutes, and she brings approximately 40 to 50 prepared meals with her. She sometimes has help from her daughter, but at other times she carries all of the weight herself. Sabina and the other members of her group will use this loan of 400.00 soles to invest in the purchase of new pots for selling their foods; the pots that they currently use are small and do not hold enough for all of their customers. Sabina’s wish is to set up a grocery store in her home, since she is tired of going out to sell meals every day so far from her home.

Translated from Spanish by Christopher Knutson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing new pots for selling their foods

loans.name: Joelor

texts.en:
Joelor V.'s main source of income comes from making and selling snacks and delicacies in her community. She is 42 years old, married and has one small child. They are from the city of Dapitan. Joelor has been in this business for over four years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2006, Joelor joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Joelor has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,900 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale.

Joelor is requesting a new loan of 14900 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products to sell. This will be her eighth loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make food products

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Our featured entrepreneur is a young and active vendor of balot (incubated 18 day old duck eggs). She is Mrs. Evelyn C., 28 years of age, married to Angelito C., a tricycle driver in the city. They are blessed with four children: three of them are now in elementary school and the other one is an infant.

With starting capital of 500 PHP from a lending investor, she was able to begin her business almost a year ago. Now she is earning an average net income of not less than 3,000 PHP. Upon hearing the good news of Paglaum MPC, she immediately joined the PDP-LP (Paglaum Development Program for Landless People) in the year 2006. With her good credit record, she has accessed multiple loans.

Now on her sixth cycle, she is applying for 8,000 PHP to buy one unit tricycle for her husband. Her hope in life is to be able to meet the daily needs of her family and give them a better education for their future.

loans.use: To purchase one unit tricycle

location.town: P6 Carmen Annex, Ozamiz City, Mis. Occ.

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
Julieta B.'s main source of income comes from raising pigs for sale. She is 39 years old, married and has four school-age children. They are from the city of Dapitan. Julieta has been in this business for over two years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month.

In 2008, Julieta joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Julieta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. Julieta is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be her third loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida D. J. is one of the most outstanding members of ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines. She is 59 years old and the mother of three. She is married to Efren, who is 58 years old. She lives in the busy town of Morong, Rizal province in the Philippines.

To remove her family from poverty and to make a decent life for her children, are her greatest desires. In 2000, she joined ASHI hoping to access capital for her business. Her previous loans were carefully and wisely spent on a sari-sari store (general store) as a primary business, and portions of her loans were also spent on the maintenance of the tricycle that her husband drives. Both of her businesses bring in enough proceeds for her family's consumption.

Now on her twelfth loan, she requests a loan of 45,000 pesos as additional capital for her store and for the maintenance of her tricycle. Specifically, the loan will be used to pay for 100 pieces of placenta soap and prepaid load for cell phones. She is optimistic that, with the trust and support of ASHI and Kiva, she can achieve her dream of expanding her business and having space in the market some day for a bigger store.

loans.use: To pay for 100 pieces of placenta soap and prepaid load for cell phones, also tricycle maintenance

loans.name: Marcela

texts.en:
Marcela S. hails from the busy town of Morong, Rizal province in the Philippines. She is 82 years old but the energy for continuing a business is still bursting in her. She is widowed and left with three children. All of her children are of legal age.

In 1998, she decided to join ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines, full of hope to have access to capital for her business. Her previous loans were wisely spent in a farming business, in partnership with her son. The business has gone well and smoothly. It brings in enough profit for herself and her family.

Now on her twelfth loan, she is asking for 40,000 pesos as additional capital for their farm to pay for supplies like fertilizers, pesticides, herbicides, labor and other farm needs.

She is optimistic that, with the support of ASHI and Kiva, she can earn more income and have extra money to save for her future. She is especially concerned for her health, since she is getting older now, and she also wants to help her grandchildren with their school fees.

loans.use: To pay for farm supplies such as fertilizers, pesticides, herbicides and labor, etc.

loans.name: Thorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Thorn Y. is a farmer who owns a small rice field and cultivates rice for a living. She is also a grocer in her village. She is a widow with two children who are attending the local school. They live in Sambuor village in Takeo province.

Since the grocery business is doing well, Mrs. Thorn Y. wants to expand it. She decided to ask for a loan to buy more grocery goods for the current business. She will use some of the loan to buy a cow for breeding.

loans.use: To buy more grocery goods

loans.name: Rosita Misksy

texts.en:
Rosita is 29 years old and married with two children. Her husband works as a security guard.  Rosita dedicates herself to the sale of soft drinks and beer as well as clothing and shoes.  

Rosita has been working with Kiva's partner Manuela Ramos for three years and belongs to the communal bank "Las Doncellas." She invested her very first loan of 300 soles (about $100) in the sale of homemade popsicles. She then continued to expand her business, first moving into the sale of drinks and then into the sale of clothing and shoes. Rosita is pleased to have become more independent with the business she has created using her loans. Rosita will use this loan of 1000 soles to purchase more of the various items that she sells.   

Rosita's goal is to eventually have her own shop for the shoes and clothing that she sells.  She also wants to make some improvements to her home.

loans.use: To buy soft drinks, beer, shoes and clothing to sell

loans.name: Pheng

texts.en: Mrs. Pheng U. lives in Brovong village in the Takeo province. She is a widow with a child who is 14 years old and still attending the local school. She is a farmer who owns a small field for cultivating rice. Since the local market is far from her house and she spends a lot of money a taxi, she decided to ask for a loan to buy a motorbike for her to travel in the local village.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her to travel in the local village

loans.name: Eteldita

texts.en:
Eteldita is 34 years old and has a business doing manicures and pedicures. She also helps her husband in his business selling construction materials, such as sand and crushed stone. Eteldita and her husband have four children.

Eteldita has been working with Kiva partner Manuela Ramos for four years and belongs to the communal bank "Las Doncellas."  Eteldita hopes to use this loan of 1,500 soles to purchase construction supplies together with her husband and also to purchase products to continue implementing her manicure/pedicure business.

Eteldita is grateful for the financial support she has received from Manuela Ramos. Thanks to this support she has not only been able to expand her business, but has also been able to purchase things for her home and send her son to a good school. Eteldita's goals are to eventually construct her own home and to continue helping her son complete his studies.

loans.use: construction materials; supplies for nail salon

loans.name: Srey

texts.en:
Mrs. Srey M. is a farmer in Chroy Slaeng village in Takeo province. She now faces a small problem in her rice farming, because her rice field is infertile. She decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers to support the field and she will use the rest of the loan to buy a pump in order to water her field.

Mrs. Srey M. is 37 years old and the mother of five children: four of whom are attending the local school and the youngest one stays at home because that child is only 5 years old. Her husband, Mr. Eim Rith, is a laborer who makes a small income to support the family. Her husband and youngest son are also present in the photo.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and a water pump

loans.name: Iris Lilia

texts.en:
Iris is 20 years old and is married with one child.  She sells cooked food and fruit in front of her home.  Iris's husband works as a motorcycle taxi driver and supports Iris in her business ventures.  

Iris has been working with Manuela Ramos, a Kiva field partner, for one year and belongs to the "Las Doncellas" communal bank. Iris used her first loan of 300 soles (about $100) to start a business selling cooked food.  With profits from this business, she was able to purchase a television and a refrigerator. Iris plans to use this loan of 1000 soles to purchase wood and roofing materials to construct a small kiosk from which to sell her products. She will also use part of the loan to buy fruit to sell and food for her restaurant business.

Iris's goal is to continue to work hard in order to build up her savings. Iris hopes to use this money to begin university studies next year in order to become a kindergarten teacher.

loans.use: Wood and roofing materials to construct a kiosk; food for a restaurant business and fruit to sell

loans.name: Mom

texts.en: Mrs. Mom N. is a villager who lives in Kraing Bonteay Village in Takeo Province. She is a farmer. Her husband, Mr. Pak Yom, is a cow middleman. Because the business is doing well, he wants to expand it, so Mrs. Mom N. has decided to ask for a loan to buy two cows for her husband's business. She is 49 years old and the mother of two children who stay at home to help their parents with their business. Her husband appears on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy two cows for her husband's business.

loans.name: Fely

texts.en:
Mrs. Fely T. is a 62-year-old woman and the mother of five children ages 17 to 28 years old. She has been happy with her life since she married Francisco, despite the poor kind of living they had then. Fely and her husband lack the education that is required to be employed. Therefore, they have used their own skills to earn money for their children and to survive. 

Francisco is a farmer who doesn't have his own land to farm. Other people in their village hire him during the rice planting and harvest season. His service fee is not enough to meet the expenses of his five children. In addition to being a mother, Fely had the courage to start her own small business to augment her husband's income. She has the skill to raise livestock in their wide and verdant backyard. However, because her business income was not enough to meet her family's expenses, she could not use it as business capital and there was no microfinance institution in their village that would trust her with a loan.

In 2005, Fely joined a group of poor women who share the same aspiration in life -- to bring their families out of poverty. With other four women, she received a loan from ASHI. From then on, Fely's business had direction and was sustained. After a series of loans from ASHI, she noticed improvements in her family's life. With her previous loan, she bought a calf and two piglets. Those piglets are already sold, and she now wants to buy more piglets to replace them, so she is applying for another loan. 

Fely has never wanted anything else in her life as a mother other than to give her children a better future by sending them to school through college. However, she failed with her four eldest children, because some of them married at an early age and others stopped going to school and worked instead. Fely's last hope is youngest child who is in the third year of high school and will soon be in college, and, also, her grandchildren.

loans.use: Buying piglets to raise in her backyard and sell after four months.

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites A.'s main source of income comes from harvesting and selling wild caught fish to local community members. She is 29 years old, married and has four school-age children. They are from the village of Puntod, Lopez Jaena, Misamis Occidental. Marites has been in her business for over 11 years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Marites joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Marites is requesting a loan of 3000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials to repair a fishing net. This will be her first loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to supplement the family's income.

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials to repair a fishing net

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Horn

texts.en: Mrs. Horn P. is a villager in Trapaing Khnol Village in Takeo Province. She is a farmer who makes a living by growing rice on a small piece of land that she owns. Her husband, Mr. Orm Ton, is a horse-cart driver who can make a little income to support the family. Although they try to work hard, they earn less income than they need to support the family. Thus, Mrs. Horn P. has decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow to breed. She has two children. One child is a farmer and the other one is studying. Her husband appear on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To o buy a cow for breeding.

loans.name: Albaida

texts.en:
Albaida is 25 years old and is single with no children. Albaida raises and sells chickens, a business that produces good profits, in the city of Pucallpa.  Albaida's business runs in a 45-day cycle.  She purchases her chicks, feeds them well, and is ready to sell them after 1.5 months when they are fully grown. Albaida raises 120 chickens at a time and reports that her earnings are improving.    

Albaida has been working with Manuela Ramos, a Kiva field partner, for one year and belongs to the "Las Doncellas" communal bank. She plans to use this loan of 1000 soles to purchase more chicks and the food that they will need.

Albaida's goal is to construct a larger chicken coop where she will be able to keep 500 chickens instead of just 120.

loans.use: Chicks and food for them

loans.name: Enebish

texts.en:
Enebish D. is a single mother who has two sons, ages 7 and 11. She lives with her children and mother in a ger (a yurt or nomadic housing tent) district on the plot of land that she owns in Arhangay, one of the Mongolian central provinces. 

Enebish started a tailoring business in 2001. Then, in 2006, she started selling second-hand clothes at the local market. She purchases used clothing that is imported from South Korea. She pays 10,000 tugrugs (about $7) for a kilo of used clothes and then resells each item for a slightly higher price. Enebish says that "many poor and vulnerable people live in our province and big portions of my buyers consist of them. Because second-hand clothes are cheaper than new clothes, they sell quicker." 

With this loan, she will purchase more second-hand clothes to increase her business inventory. In the near future, she is planning to start a business selling new clothing.

loans.use: To purchase more second-hand clothes

loans.name: Zobeida

texts.en:
Zobeida is 34 years old and dedicates herself to the sale of the "Unique" brand of beauty products. She is married and has three young children. Zobeida's husband works as a truck driver. 

Zobeida has been working with Manuela Ramos, a Kiva field partner, for about 2.5 years and belongs to the "Las Doncellas" communal bank. She hopes to invest this loan of 1000 soles in more beauty products for her business.

Zobeida is grateful to Manuela Ramos for giving her the financial support she needed to start her business. She is pleased to be able to earn her own income and to support her family. In the future, Zobeida hopes to build a store where she can offer her products to customers. Expanding her business in this way will help her to achieve her ultimate goal of supporting her children through their education.

Zobeida is pictured here with a few of her products as well as with some of the prizes she has earned for good sales volume.

loans.use: To buy beauty products to sell

loans.name: Emelita

texts.en:
Mrs. Emelita B., age 46, is the mother of four children and the wife of a 50-year-old farmer. Emelita and her family live a very simple life in a remote village of the municipality of Dao in Antique, a province where mountains meet the sea. 

For six years, Emelita has raised and sold animals in her backyard. With the money she earns from the business, she pays for the expenses of her family, especially the education of her children. She thought of having this business because she loves tender animals.

In 2008, when she became a member of ASHI, she focused on raising chicken and ducks, instead of other animals. With the two animals she chose, she had eggs to sell and fresh meat for the market. Now that Emelita is on her second loan with ASHI, she plans to buy more chicks and ducklings for her business to grow. 

She has a dream that she works hard for -- sending her two younger children to school -- because her eldest and second child are not in school anymore. Her eldest is a graduate in criminology and works as a security guard and her second child is a high school graduate.

loans.use: To buy chicks and ducklings

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria is 50 years old and earns income by renting out a motorcycle taxi that she owns. Maria is married and has 5 children. Four are adults and one is still dependent on her. Her husband is a retired teacher.

Maria has been working with Manuela Ramos, a Kiva field partner for two years and belongs to the "Las Doncellas" communal bank. She plans to use this loan of 1000 soles to purchase spare parts and to do maintenance work on her motorcycle taxi. Maria used her first loan of 300 soles (about $100) to invest in fruit to sell. Little by little, she saved her earnings until she was able to purchase her motorcycle taxi. This taxi earns her money every day.  

Maria has two goals. She wants to keep working so she can send her 13-year-old son to college and he can have a professional career.  She also would like to have her own small grocery shop.

loans.use: Spare parts and maintenance work on a motorcycle taxi

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa F. is from the village of Canicapan. She is 46 years old. Elsa is separated and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Elsa operates a food products business. Elsa has been engaged in her business for 5 years and earns approximately Php1,000.00 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Elsa joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elsa is requesting a loan amounting to 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be Elsa's first loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make food to sell

loans.name: Mila Angelica

texts.en:
Mila is 33 years old. She is married and has three children. Mila sells juice and cooked food. Her husband works as a motorcycle taxi driver.

Mila has been working with Manuela Ramos, a Kiva field partner  for 1.5 years and is a member of the "Las Doncellas" communal bank. She plans to use this loan of 1200 soles to purchase spare parts for the motorcycle taxi that her husband drives, and also to purchase fruit and other necessities for her juice business.

With her loans from Manuela Ramos Mila, has been growing her own business as well as helping her husband with his work. Mila has been able to purchase two motorcycle taxis with her loans. Eventually, Mila would like to generate more income by running a small grocery shop out of her home. She hopes to continue helping her husband and children.

loans.use: Spare parts for a motorcycle taxi; fruits and other ingredients for making juice

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en:
66-year-old Elvira L. is the mother of two children. Now she is also a supportive grandmother to her grandchildren. After the death of her husband, Elvira had her children and grandchildren to think about and to have a reason for living. 

Her membership in ASHI since 1997 has given her a chance to have her own business and to keep herself busy. From an initial loan of Php 5,000, she can now borrow Php 25,000 and can even reach the peak amount in the future, because she has maintained her excellent performance thoughout her membership in ASHI. Therefore, Elvira's wish of expanding her business with the help of her eldest child, who is her business partner, is about to happen, because it has now grown, although not yet to the extent that she expects. 

When she will reach the highest amount ASHI can offer to lend her, she plans to rent a space in the market where she can sell dried fish. With the opportunities she can get from her membership in ASHI, she can also help her children send their children to school. When she passes away, at least she has made her business successful and her children can own a business some day.

loans.use: To buy dried fish. A small amount will be used to travel to buy the product.

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Mrs. Myrna B., age 47, is the wife of Recolito and the mother of four children, ages 13 -22 years old. Her eldest child is a college graduate, her second child is still studying in college, and the last two are in high school. Both Myrna and her husband lack education, so they have not been employed by any offices. However, Myrna did not accept that as a reason not to earn money and to have a better life. Instead, she and her husband helped one another. 

In 1996, Myrna found an opportunity to acquire business capital. She joined ASHI and she was inspired by the stories of poor women of ASHI. She wanted to become successful like them. Therefore, the loans that she has taken since then are used for her business. Because of the opportunity to borrow, Myrna was able to open variety store and sell vegetables and, recently, she started selling fish. She is courageous enough to take all the risks of running a business. She thought she could be successful because her husband is there to support her and because of a dream she kept in her mind -- having all of her remaining children graduate from college. 

Myrna had never hoped anything but to prevent her children from experiencing the hard life that she and her husband had experienced.

loans.use: Vegetables, fish, and to finance her variety store.

loans.name: Ma. Leslie

texts.en:
Ma. Leslie V. is a 40-year-old mother of four children and the wife of Jerry, a government employee. Despite the fact that Ma. Leslie’s husband earns a salary every month from the government, she has not tied herself to the role of being just a mother and a wife. She wanted to be an entrepreneur and augment her husband's income, especially with the increasing financial demand of the education of her children, two of whom are in college and the other two are in high school. 

To enhance he productive role being a woman, Ma. Leslie joined ASHI in 2006 with the knowledge of her husband. She then used her loan to start a food vending business. Ma. Leslie loves to cook. She can satisfy the appetites of her children the way she satisfies the appetites of her customers. Eventually, Ma. Leslie’s business grew and she had saved money from her profits. The amount of loan she is qualified to borrow from ASHI grew, too, so she was able to start another business. She then bought a tricycle -- a motorcycle with an attached sidecar – to use as a public utility vehicle.

Ma. Leslie’s present loan applied will be used for her food vending business and some portions will be spent for the renewal of her tricycle licenses and franchise.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for her food business. A small portion will be used for the tricycle maintenance.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase furniture materials

loans.name: Lina

texts.en:
LINA S. is 38 years old, married with 2 school-age children, and a resident of Brgy. Canjusa, Pulupandan, Negros Occidental.

Lina joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1997 because she did not want her family to be wholly dependent on her husband's income, which was really not enough to support their needs especially with two growing kids. 

So Lina ventured into seafood processing and sales. In the picture, Lina is shown posing in front of beds of krill being prepared for Ginamos production. Lina just paid off her previous loan of PHP 29,500.00. For this 16th loan cycle she needs to borrow PHP 15,000 to sustain her expanding business. 

Having her own business has given her the confidence and the independence she wants in her married life. She realizes that earning her own income to help her husband support their children has made their family unit even stronger.
 
What is Ginamos?

Ginamos is a generic Hiligaynon (the local dialect in Western Visayas) term for anything that is salted and aged to ferment - in Tagalog it is known as Bagoong. Ginamos can also refer to fermented salted fish, mussels, oysters, etc. but in general, the term Ginamos refers to mashed salted fermented krill - all the others must be qualified - e.g. Ginamos na isda (fermented salted fish) or Ginamos na Tahong (fermented salted mussels).

Ginamos is prepared by mashing sea salt and krill together until the salt is well mixed into the finely ground krill, then it is kept in containers to age until ready. Ginamos in Negros Island is usually moist but firm and sold by the block or smaller bricks. Vendors usually pre-cut the blocks into different sizes to offer the buyers a selection. People usually buy Ginamos either as a flavor enhancer to dishes like Pinakbet (a vegetable stew) or as a dish by itself. When cooked as a dish, it is usually mixed with vinegar and sauteed with lots of garlic and sometimes with fried pork rind, and is served with rice as a meal or with green mangoes as an appetizer.


 
About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: ADDITIONAL CAPITAL TO EXPAND HER BUSINESS OPERATIONS

loans.name: Fred

texts.en:
Fred is a widower and the father of five children. He has served as mother and father to his five children. He was having a hard time disciplining his children, because he is also responsible for providing for his family's daily needs and for the daily school necessities of his children. Fred is a very good model father. He is very responsible and is not an in-favor father. He is patient and works hard to fulfill his duties and responsibilities for his family's welfare. 

To earn an income each day, Fred runs a jeep transport service from the village of Sili, where they live, to the market. As much as possible, Fred wanted to double his work time to generate a higher daily income for his children. He is requesting the support of Kiva to maintain the used jeep that he uses in his transportation business. He hopes to borrow PHP 9,000 for vehicle maintenance.

loans.use: Jeep maintenance

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en: Marilyn is the mother of four children. It is not easy to provide them with the education they need to have a better future but she is doing her best, with the support of her husband, Eugenio A.. Her family lives simply in the village of Catabban in Burgos, Isabela. She manages a general store in their village to help her husband earn a daily income for their family's needs. Her store still lacks merchandise to sell, so Marilyn is requesting a loan from Kiva of PHP 18,000. She wants her business to grow and become stable in the future. She is thankful that she learned about Kiva loans and hopes that you can help her.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma L. is from the village of San Isidro Bajo. She is 50 years old. Norma is a widow with four adult children. To make a living, Norma sells a variety of products to local community members. Norma has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately Php 2,000.00 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Norma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Norma is requesting a loan of  5,000 PHP, which will be used to expand the business. This will be the first loan taken out by Norma from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchased additional products to sell

loans.name: Magdalena

texts.en:
Magdalina P. is from the village of Sta. Cruz Jimenez. She is 29 years old. Magdalina is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Magdalina raises pigs for sale. Magdalina has been engaged in her business for 10 years and earns approximately Php 2,000.00 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Magdalina joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Magdalina is requesting a loan of 3,000 PHP, which will be used to expand the business. This will be Magdalina's first loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase piglets for fattening

loans.name: Rosanna

texts.en:
ROSANNA P. is 45 years old, married 3 children ranging from school age to adult, and a resident of Brgy. Sampinit, Bago City, Negros Occidental.

Rosanna used to grow and sell a variety of vegetables to earn a living for her family, but it always fell short, so when she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon, she used her 3rd cycle loan to buy ducklings to raise and sell to supplement the income she earns from the vegetables.

She also discovered that raising free-range ducks was not very hard - she released them into the fields to feed in the morning and she gathered them back to their pen for safekeeping in the afternoon. And it generated a very good return for her, enough to cover her family's needs.

Now on her 9th loan cycle, Rosanna wants to borrow PHP 6,000.00 to purchase new ducklings to raise and sell, so that she could continue supplementing her family's income with the much needed funds from this venture.

Rosanna hopes that by expanding her livestock raising she will be able to provide for her family's financial needs and secure her children's future.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: THE PURCHASE OF DUCKINGS TO RAISE AND SELL

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia A. is from the village of Katipunan. She is 52 years old. Lydia is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Lydia raises crops to sell. Lydia has been engaged in her business for over 22 years and earns approximately Php 1,600.00 a month from these activities.

In 2008, Lydia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lydia is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to expand her business. This will be Lydia's third loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchase fertilizer such as manure

loans.name: Nena

texts.en:
Nena B. is from the village of Canicapan. She is 56 years old. Nena is married and has 2 adult children. To make a living, Nena buys and sells clothes in the local community. Nena has been engaged in her business for 1 year and earns approximately Php 2,100.00 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Nena joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nena is requesting a loan of 3,000 PHP, which will be used to expand her business. This will be Nena's first loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand the business

loans.name: Hadjah Nalongo’S Group

texts.en:
Hadjah is a leader of a 5-member loan group. She is a 33-year-old married woman with six children between the ages of  5 and 16 years. All of her children go to school. She owns a two-room house where she lives with nine people. Hadjah takes care of additional family members. There is electricity but no piped water at her home.  The family gets two meals a day. She lives and works in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala. 

Hadjah stays in Nalukolongo where she runs a ladies saloon in one of Kampala's suburbs. She uses public transportation to and from shopping because she buys from Kampala city shops. Hadjah sells to an average of  20 people a day and sells to all categories of people. She works seven days a week. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and rent for her business premises and her home.  She has been in this business for the past 6 years. 

Hadjah has been with MCDT for over six years and is servicing her twelfth loan, and is still working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more food for her restaurant. Hadjah aspires to see her business grow bigger and own a permanent business premise.

loans.use: To buy more food for her restauarnt

loans.name: Reny

texts.en: Reny is a mother of two children, Warren and Lawren. She serves as a simple housewife while managing a typical village store in their house. She is married to Walden B., a 42-year-old farmer. While doing her house chores daily, Reny is also manages her store in order to gain income for her family's necessities and to provide her children with their daily allowances in school. They live peacefully and happily despite the difficulties of life. Her dream is to become a successful business woman. That’s why she always works hard and is very patient with every challenge of life. She hopes that her business progresses in the future so that she will able to improve their poor living situation. That is why she is requesting a loan from Kiva of PHP 18, 000. She will use funds as additional business capital for her to develop a better business in the future.

loans.use: ADDITIONAL CAPITAL

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites manages a general store. She is an entrepreneur who lives harmoniously with her family in the rural village of Sili Aurora, Isabela. She is 38 years old and is married to Jose Y. who is 40 years old. The couple was still lucky because, in her menopausal age, she was blessed with a child named Kaye Ann, who is now 5 years of age. Marites and her husband are doing their best to give their only child a bright future. Jose, her husband, maintains their farm lot while Marites brings out her best in developing her store. 

To further improve the performance of her store, Marites is requesting a loan of PHP 13,000 from Kiva. The loan funds will serve as additional working capital to buy the most needed merchandise to stock and some added commodities to sell so that she will able to increase her daily income. Marites dreams of becoming a successful business woman someday and she hopes that, through Kiva, she will turn her dreams into reality.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina is a hardworking entrepreneur in the village of Sili Aurora, Isabela. She is married to Reynaldo V., who is a simple farmer and who sometimes operates a tricycle transport to help generate income for their daily needs at home.

Agriculture is the main business of Gina's family: they grow corn, rice and vegetables. Gina vends vegetables, most of which come from her family's own vegetable crops. Gina sells her vegetables at wholesale prices in the public market of Aurora. She is happy that she is generating enough income to support her family's daily needs and the education of her children.

Gina wants her business to become more developed and to someday produce bigger volumes of vegetables. She is working to achieve this ambition of the sustainability of their business in order to secure her family's comfort and contentment in life. For this reason, Gina is requesting to borrow PHP26,000 from Kiva as additional business capital for her vegetable business.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Lina

texts.en: Lina is already 35 years old. She has two children who are both studying in college. She is married to Leoncio A., 37, who is a part-time house carpenter in the village of rural village of Catabban Burgos, Isabela. Their major source of income is farming, and the family's daily needs are also supported by Lina's fish vending business and her husband's labor work in carpentry. In addition, Lina also raises livestock and even earns income through direct selling of AVON products in their village. The couple strives in their business endeavors in order to continue sending their children to school. Lina wants to improve her business, so she is requesting a Kiva loan of PHP 7,000.

loans.use: Business improvement

loans.name: Sylivia Nakawooya’S Group

texts.en:
Sylvia is the leader of a group of four members. She is 24 years old and married with two children aged 1 and 3 years. One of her children goes to school. She owns a two-room house where she is staying with five people. Sylvia takes care of additional family members. There is electricity and no piped water at her home. The family gets two meals a day.

Sylvia resides and works in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala. Sylvia sells passion fruits in Nakulabye market in one of Kampala's suburbs She incurs extra transport costs traveling to and from shopping at Owino market, one of the busiest markets. Sylvia sells to an average of 30 people a day and sells to all categories of people. She works six days a week. Sylvia sells mainly on a retail basis. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and rent for her business premises.

Sylvia has been in this business for the last 5 years She has been with MCDT for over two years and is applying for her fourth loan, working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of passion fruits and oranges. Sylvia aspires to see her business grow bigger and to own permanent business premises. .

loans.use: To buy more sacks of fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Divina

texts.en:
Divina A. is engaged in a general store business. Her husband Roger is a farmer in their village of Catabban Burgos, Isabela. They have three children to whom they give their full support for a brighter future. Two of her children have already finished college and now have their own jobs. Truly, hard work and patience pays, said Divina. Divina is hoping that her youngest child, who is currently studying, will also finish his studies if she works hard and perseveres in her business development.

Divina is requesting a loan from Kiva amounting to PHP10,000 as additional business capital. She will use the loan to purchase more merchandise for her retail business, such as canned and bottled goods, soaps, shampoo, breads, biscuits, kitchen commodities, etc. She hope to further increase her daily income from the business.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise for her general store

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en:
With this loan of PHP25,000 loan from Kiva, Caroline hopes to able to improve her general store business and maintain her small eatery located in the village of Sili Aurora, Isabela, where her family is living happily. Caroline is already 49 years old, and her husband Joseph is already 54 years of age. They are blessed with four children: Jocelyn, Joseph, Jacquelyn, and Charles Andrew.

Caroline's business enable her to support her family, especially the expensess for her youngest son, who is now in his fourth year of high school in preparation for college. Caroline wishes to become successful in her business through hard work, patience, and continued assistance from Kiva loans. Caroline also believes that everything is possible if we commit to God.

loans.use: Business improvement

loans.name: Lukia Ssekana’S Group

texts.en:
Lukia is a leader of five members of a group.  She is 38 years old and married with three children aged 5 and 16 years. All her children go to school. She resides in and owns a four-room house where she is staying with nine people. Lukia takes care of additional family members. There is electricity and no piped water at her home.  The family gets two meals a day. She resides and works in a semi urban area, which is in the outskirts of Kampala.  Lukia stays in Kawala selling second hand clothes in Kawala market in one of Kampala suburbs.  She uses public transport to and from shopping as she buys from Owino market, one of the busiest markets in Uganda.  Lukia sells to an average of 20 people a day and sells to all categories of people. She works seven days a week. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and daily market dues. She has been in this business for the last ten years Lukia has been with MCDT for over six years and is servicing her twelfth loan, working all this long with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more clothes for resale. Lukia aspires to see her business grow bigger and to own a permanent business premise. 

.

loans.use: To buy more bales of clothes

loans.name: Dominga

texts.en: “Praying without ceasing” is the principle in life shared by Dominga B., a simple entrepreneur who is seeking financial assistance for her businesses. At her age of 43, Dominga still is energetic and determined to become successful in her chosen business. She manages a furniture making business in their simple village of Catabban Burgos, Isabela. She also operates a little eatery business in the village and raises pigs. She is married to Jose B., a farmer and her partner in managing her business well. They are gifted with three children namely: Gemma, Jeremy, and Emerald. Gemma is a college student taking up computer programming. Jeremy is still in high school and Emerald is an elementary pupil. She is living with her family, happy and helping each other to maintain the good bonding they currently have. Her dream is to expand their business further, thus requesting to borrow a loan from Kiva amounting to PHP32,000 for additional business capital.

loans.use: Business capital

loans.name: Dominador

texts.en: Dominador operates a general store and raises livestock, where some of the daily income from his store is invested. He is already 58 years old and is doing his best despite his retiring age to become successful in his business endeavor. He married Remedios who used to help him most of the time in their store. Luckily, the couple is blessed with three children: Remelyn, Marlon, and Jinky. His dream is to continue to maintain his business to sustain their family's daily needs. To earn further income, Dominador used to wake up very early in the morning to open his store for early customers to buy and not close till 9:00 in the evening. He sacrifices a lot in the business just to sustain his family's important necessities. This is the main reason why he is asking for financial support from Kiva amounting to PHP14,000 as additional business capital.

loans.use: Business capital

loans.name: Perlita

texts.en:
Perlita A. is from the village of Bato. She is 45 years old. Perlita is married and has five adult children. To make a living, Perlita owns & operates a business making & selling general household furniture to local businesses and community members. Perlita has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Perlita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Perlita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture. Perlita is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory & as working capital. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Perlita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & as working capital

loans.name: Jerry

texts.en:
Being a family breadwinner, Jerry is doing his best to provide his family with sufficient necessities for their daily living and to sustain the education of his two children. He is thankful for having a wife like Melony, (his wife), for she is so caring and a good mother to his children. Jerry and wife help each other maintain both their cell phone load retailing and hog raising businesses in the village of Catabban Bugros, Isabela where his family is peacefully living. The couple also maintains a corn field where they get their major source of income. 

Jerry is also aiming to have a progressive business where he can generate a bigger income to save for the future college education of their two children who are both in high school. Thus, he wants to avail a loan from Kiva amounting to PHP16,000 additional capital.

loans.use: As additional capital

loans.name: Felicitas

texts.en: Felicitas is very lucky to have a good and loving husband, neighbors usually say to Felicitas. She is the manager of her own general store in their rural village of Catabban Burgos, Isabela. She is married to Livegildo D., a kind and hard working farmer. While Felicitas is taking care of her general store, her husband manages their farm lot and maintains their hog raising business. The couple helps each other to improve their living situation, to become progressive and give their five children a better living. Through their business with hard work, patience, sacrifice, loyalty, and faith in God, they successfully sent their children to school though their youngest still is studying at the moment. To further maintain their business, Felicitas is asking the support of Kiva to lend her the amount of PHP10,000 as additional business capital. She promises to work hard so that somehow she will be able to pay the loan and become successful someday to prove to others that “poverty is not a hindrance to success”.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Arnold

texts.en:
Arnold manages a typical village store business in their simple place of Barangay Catabban Burgos, Isabela. According to him, managing a store is of big help in maintaining some important family resources such farming, and other alternative businesses.

Arnold now is 40 years old and is patiently doing his best to give his family enough financial support. He is married to Janet, 39 years old. Her accompaniment in their humble store is a great help, said Arnold. They are lucky because they are blessed with three children who are in their high school studies. His dream is to sustain his business to give his family a progressive and stable living condition.

Arnold is hoping that through this Kiva loan, he will be able to generate additional business capital of PHP 12,000 to purchase added merchandise.

loans.use: To use as additional business capital

loans.name: Aurea

texts.en: Aurea S. is from the village of Bato. She is 57 years old, is married, and has four adult children. Aurea owns and operates a business raising crops, primarily planting and harvesting rice for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over forty years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2001, Aurea joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Aurea is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seed, seedlings and young crops to raise. This loan will be her 14th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seed, seedlings and young crops to raise

loans.name: Felicidad

texts.en:
FELICIDAD S. is a 58 year-old widow who lives in Brgy. Canjusa, Pulupandan, Negros Occidental.

Felicidad has earned a living selling "Ginamos", a local delicacy made from fermented salted krill, for 30 years of her life. When her husband died, she became depressed from her loss that she thought of giving up her business, but with no adult children to support her, she realized that she had to plan ahead and be financially self-sufficient in her old age. 

With the moral support of her friends and the encouragement from Project Dungganon, Felicidad decided to continue with her Ginamos business, which now provides sufficiently for her by netting an average of PHP 7,000 per month.

For her 12th loan cycle, Felicidad is borrowing PHP 18,000.00 to add to her capital so that she could have more Ginamos to sell. The advantage of Ginamos over other food stuff is that like fine wine, it improves with age. 

What is Ginamos?

Ginamos is a generic Hiligaynon (the local dialect in Western Visayas) term for anything that is salted and aged to ferment - in Tagalog it is known as Bagoong. Ginamos can also refer to fermented salted fish, mussels, oysters, etc. but in general, the term Ginamos refers to mashed salted fermented krill - all the others must be qualified - e.g. Ginamos na isda (fermented salted fish) or Ginamos na Tahong (fermented salted mussels).

Ginamos is prepared by mashing sea salt and krill together until the salt is well mixed into the finely ground krill, then it is kept in containers to age until ready. Ginamos in Negros Island is usually moist but firm and sold by the block or smaller bricks. Vendors usually pre-cut the blocks into different sizes to offer the buyers a selection. People usually buy Ginamos either as a flavor enhancer to dishes like Pinakbet (a vegetable stew) or as a dish by itself. When cooked as a dish, it is usually mixed with vinegar and sauteed with lots of garlic and sometimes with fried pork rind, and is served with rice as a meal or with green mangoes as an appetizer.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: ADDITIONAL WORKING CAPITAL FOR THE BORROWER

loans.name: Estelita

texts.en:
Estelita is now 48 years old and is married to Edemar D. R.. They are blessed with three children namely: Edilmar Lisa, Jay, and Edimar. Her children already have their own families and, at her age, Estelita already has grandchildren and one of them lives with her.

Estelita lives in the rural village of Catabban Burgos, Isabela. In the village her family lives simply, with farming as their main source of income. Estelita is raising a pig in their backyard to generate additional income for their needs. At the moment, Estelita is the one responsible for sending her grandson’s niece to school. She helps her husband in generating income for their family.

Estelita wants to borrow PHP 10,000 from Kiva as additional capital for her hog-raising and fish-vending businesses. She wants to sustain her businesses in order give her grandson and niece an education they will be able to treasure for the rest of their lives. She believes that hard work and patience are the best remedies in overcoming the difficulties of life.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital

loans.name: Tomasa

texts.en:
Tomasa N. is a hardworking resident of Barangay Sili in the peaceful municipality of Aurira, Isabela. The Filipino citrus fruit, calamansi, makes their municipality known to other nearby municipalities.

Tomasa is married to Virgilio who is a simple farmer producing rice, corn and calamansi. They are blessed with two children who are now attending the high school and elementary level of education. Tomasa hopes for the best for her children so that they will have a progressive future someday.

Tomasa is engaged in managing a general store business in their village. Her business income enables her to finance their daily needs at home and to provide a daily allowances for her two children. She manages her store well to be able maintain a good daily income.

However, due to lack of capital, she is still not contented with her daily business performance. Thus, she wanted to borrow PHP 30,000 from Kiva to use as additional business capital to buy more goods and merchandise that are salable and in demand by her customers. She believes that having enough capital is a big help in developing a better business. For this reason, she is hoping that Kiva will grant her loan request and she will utilize it wisely for the development of her store.

loans.use: To use as additional business capital

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: Maria P. is from the village of Bato. She is 38 years old, is married, and has three school-aged children. Maria owns and operates a business raising crops, primarily planting and harvesting rice for sale. She is just starting this business. In 2008, Maria joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional seed, seedlings and young crops to raise. Maria is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be her 2nd from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan P. is a mother of patience and hard work. She is requesting Kiva to assist her financially in her dress-making business in their village of Sili Aurora, Isabela. Susan is already 47 years old. She is married to Joey who is now 49 years of age and is a farmer. They are gifted with two children namely: Jerome and Jerry.

Susan makes clothing with the aid of an old sewing machine. Her business helps them support their family expenses, especially those of her youngest son who is taking his second year in college in Information Technology. Sometimes, Susan’s husband works part time driving a passenger tricycle from which they also get some extra income to provide their important necessities at home.

Susan is hoping that through Kiva loans, her business will further improve to earn enough daily income.

loans.use: To use for business improvement

loans.name: Amalia

texts.en:
Amalla L. is engaged in hog-raising. She is also selling vegetables in her humble vending stall located just in front of their house in the village of Catabban Burgos, Isabela. She is already 42 years old and is married to Bernardo L., now 52 years old. The couple is blessed with four children of whom their youngest is the one left attending school in college, taking up an education course.

Amalla shared with us that her family's major source of income is farming. She manages her hog-raising to be able to help her husband in their farming and cover family necessities. She wants to further develop her business to progress in order to give sufficient support to her family, especially for the education of her youngest child. Seeking the support of Kiva loans is the option she learned about. She hopes to borrow PHP 12,000 as additional business capital to improve her hog-raising business and to purchase at least 2 or 3 sacks of feed to supply the daily food of the livestock till they are ready for disposal.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Komi

texts.fr:
Ce monsieur est un tailleur, il jouit d’une très bonne réputation dans son quartier. Il voudrait acheter une nouvelle machine à pleinte pour exécuter et livrer à temps ses commandes.
Il sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter une machine à pleinte, ainsi il pourra livrer rapidement ses commandes et en recevoir plus pour augmenter ses recettes.
Etant célibataire, le revenu de son activité lui permet de subvenir à ses propres charges et à celles de ses frères et sœurs.
texts.en:
This man is a tailor, who enjoys a very good reputation in his neighborhood. He would like to buy a new sewing machine to execute his orders on time. This is why he's seeking a loan from Kiva's partner, WAGES. This will enable him to execute orders faster and, therefore, to get more of them and to increase his profit. Being single, his income enables him to provide for himself and for his brothers and sisters.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine

loans.name: Ana

texts.en:
Ana A. is from the village of Bato. She is 57 years old. Ana is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Ana owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Ana has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2005, Ana joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ana has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Ana is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds and seedlings to grow. This will be the 8th loan taken out by Ana from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds and seedlings

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia is already 51 years old. She is married to Lope U., 54 years old, who is a farmer. They are gifted with four children; the youngest is taking her college level education at present.

Virginia is willing to continue sending her child to school until she finishes her college level of education. Through her general store business where she gets income for her family needs, Viriginia is requesting to access additional business capital amounting to PHP 17,000 to improve her store and increase her daily income in order to satisfy the needs of her family, especially the education of her children.

Aside from managing a typical village store, Virginia also maintains a hog-raising business and even ventures into vegetable vending to have extra income sources. She hopes that someday, through her hard work and patience, she will able to uplift their present low standard of living.

loans.use: business improvement

loans.name: Mazalo

texts.fr: Pour aider son mari qui est un chauffeur dans la prise en charge de leurs 02 enfants et dans diverses charges du foyer, cette femme a commencé le commerce  de bois de chauffage, elle s’approvisionne à tsévié car le bois de chauffage est moins coûteux, ce qui lui permet de gagner plus de profits. Une partie de son stock est épuisée, elle veut se réapprovisionner et sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter 10 tas de bois de chauffage.
texts.en:
To help her husband, who is a driver, in supporting their 2 children and with the various household expenses, this woman started selling firewood. She gets her supplies in Tsévié, because firewood is cheaper there, which enables her to increase her profits. Part of her stock has run out, and she would like to resupply. She's seeking a loan from Kiva's partner, WAGES, to buy 10 bundles of firewood.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 10 bundles of firewood

loans.name: Cherrybel

texts.en:
Cherrybel is already 23 years old. She is married to Michael A., 26 years old, who is a private employee and a farmer at the same time. They already have two children, namely Kristina Cassandra, 4 years old and Misha Carla, 4 months old.

Cherrybel wanted to join Kiva loans because of her willingness to help her husband in supporting their family's daily needs, especially their two children who will soon enter school. She wants to access a loan in the amount of PHP 10,000 and she hopes that lenders will provide her the amount to further develop her hog-raising business that she is currently managing. She will utilize the loan in purchasing sacks of feed/hog growers for her pigs.

loans.use: business development

loans.name: Gladys' Group

texts.en:
Gladys is the leader of a 5-member group. She is 48 years old, married, with six children aged between 19 and 29. She resides in and rents a one-roomed house where she is living with four people. Gladys takes care of additional family members. There is electricity but no piped water at her home. The family gets two meals a day.

Gladys resides and works in a semi-urban area which is on the outskirts of Kampala. Gladys lives in Naguru, running a little restaurant in Naguru market in one of Kampala's suburbs. She uses public transport to and from shopping as she buys from Owino markert, one of the busiest markets in Uganda.

Gladys sells to an average of 20 people a day and sells to all categories of people. She works six days a week. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and daily market dues and rent. She has been in this business for the last ten years.

Gladys has been with MCDT for over six years and is servicing her tenth loan, working all this time with the same group-mates. She wants to use this loan to stock more food for her little restaurant, such as rice and maize flour for resale. Gladys aspires to see her business grow bigger and own permanent business premises and a home. .

loans.use: To buy more rice, maize flour, and other foodstuffs for her restaurant

loans.name: Afi

texts.fr:
Cette femme exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de produits d’alimentation générale, elle exerce son commerce au marché local d’adidogomé depuis 2005. La demande actuelle de ses clients est élevée, pour les satisfaire elle doit se réapprovisionner raison pour laquelle, elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 4 cartons de spaghettis, 6 bidons d’huile « nioto », 4 bidons moyens d’huile rouge, 1 carton de détergents « momo magic » et divers produits de premières nécessités.
Elle est mariée et a 01 enfant.
texts.en:
This is a woman who earns revenues from commerce in grocery items. She has been operating at the local market of Adidogomé since 2005. The customer demand is high right now. To satisfy it, she must stock up again, which is why she's requesting a loan from WAGES in order to buy four boxes of spaghetti, six drums of "nioto" oil, four middle-sized drums of red palm oil, one box of Momo Magic detergent, and various necessities. She is married and has one child.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For buying grocery items to sell

loans.name: Cherley

texts.en:
To uplift their living situation from poverty is one of the dreams of Cherley E. a hog-raiser in the village of Siempre Viva Sur Mallig, Isabela. She is 47 years old and already a widow.  She believes that unity, patience and hard work are essentials to become successful in life. She solely works for the welfare of her four children.
