texts.en: Beatrice E. sells Fan Milk ice cream at Elmina. Beatrice has a senior high school education.  She is divorced and has four dependents. Beatrice has been selling Fan Milk ice cream since 2004. She is responsible for paying school fees and other bills. Her loan will be used to buy more ice cream for resale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save and build a house.

loans.use: To buy more ice cream for resale

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en: Eunice T. sells used clothing at Elmina. Eunice has a senior high school education. She is a single parent and has two children. Eunice has been selling used clothing since 2007. She is responsible for paying school fees and bills. Her loan will be used to buy more used clothing for resale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save and reinvest.

loans.use: To buy used clothing for resale

loans.name: Christina

texts.en: Christina C. is married and has three children. She has received schooling through senior high school. Christina sells soft drinks in Elmina, which she has done since 2009. Her husband is a security officer. Christina uses her income for school fees and other bills. Christina will use the loan to purchase more soft drinks for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Christina plans to save some money and educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase more soft drinks for resale

loans.name: Francisca

texts.en:
Francisca runs a restaurant called 'El Rocoto' in the city of Pucallpa. The restaurant is named after a type of very hot chili pepper. 'El Rocoto' specializes in ceviche, a typical regional dish consisting of fresh fish marinated in lemon juice and spices. The restaurant is open for breakfast and lunch, Monday through Saturday. Francisca does the cooking and her adult daughter and another employee serve the customers. Francisca eventually hopes to begin serving dinner as well.

Francisca has been working with Kiva partner, Manuela Ramos, for about four or five years. She used her very first loan of 300 PEN to purchase candy and soft drinks for sale. She plans to use this loan of 1000 PEN to purchase soft drinks, tablecloths and some other goods needed for her restaurant.  

Francisca was widowed 15 years ago and has had to work hard to raise her three children, now aged 26, 23, and 21.  Only the youngest still depends on her. Francisca is very appreciative of her loans from Manuela Ramos. Her credit has helped her to expand her business.  

Francisca's dream is to set up a beauty salon (for haircuts and manicures/pedicures) in the front part of her home, which is located next door to her restaurant. She has studied cosmetology in the past and has knowledge of how to run such a business. Francisca has already purchased some of the necessary materials and hopes to open her salon before the end of the year.

loans.use: To purchase soft drinks, tablecloths, and other goods

loans.name: Pacanquim Group

texts.es: Un grupo de personas llamado "Pacamquim" de la aldea Parraxchaj del municipio de San Bartolo departamento de Totonicapán, Guatemala, conformado por doce personas entre ellos hombres y mujeres, en su mayoria se dedican a la crianza de animales confección de prendas de vestir y en la venta de ropa nueva, se ha organizado en el año 2006 como grupo de apollo hacia ellos mismos para la venta de sus productos de cada actividad que realizan, ya que los señores que conforman el grupo tienen que transportar todos los productos en cada fin de semana a un lugar llamado San Francisco El Alto que se encuentra en un aproximado de 45 kilometros de donde viven, el costo de transporte es demasiado caro para trasladarse a San Francisco El Alto por esa razon son los señores quienes llevan las mercancias, animales, y entre otros productos a los marchantes del mercado de dicho lugar, y como se dieron cuenta que el negocio que realizan les deja buena ganancia, decidieron acudir a la Asociación ASDIR, a adquirir un préstamo, para poder incrementar el negocio y asi poder solventar los gastos de familia, y asi mismo mejorar las condiciones de vida de sus familias.
texts.en:
We are a group of people called “Pacamquim” from the town of Parraxchaj in the municipality of San Bartolo, the department of Totonicapan, Guatamala. There are twelve men and women in our group, We work raising animals, making clothes and selling new clothes. We organized as a group in 2006. It is a support group centered around the sale of our products. The people in our group all transport their products each weekend to a place called San Francisco El Alto. This town is about forty-five minutes away from the place that we live. The transportation costs are pretty expensive because we have to transport animals, merchandise and other products to the dealers in the market in San Francisco El Alto. We realize that the business that we do earns a good profit. So we decided to look to the Association ASDIR to apply for a loan so that we can grow our business. In this way we are able to meet our family expenses and in doing so can improve the life of our families.

Translated from Spanish by Esther Levandoski, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase our capital

loans.name: Helena

texts.en:
Helena M. is married and has five dependents. She has received schooling through primary school.

Helena sells wheat, water, bread and soft drinks in Elmina, which she has done since 1999. Her husband is self-employed. Helena uses her income to pay for school fees and bills.

Helena will use the loan to buy more food supplies for resale to expand her business. With the new profits from her expanded business, she plans to save and educate her children.

loans.use: To buy more food supplies for resale

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace M. is divorced and has four dependents. She has received schooling through senior high school.

Grace sells fresh fish in Elmina, which she has done since 2006. She uses her income to pay school fees and bills. She will use the loan to purchase more fish for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Grace plans to save and to reinvest in her business.

loans.use: To purchase more fish for resale

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn M. sells feeding bottles, nursing equipment and soft drinks in Elmina. She is married with five dependents and has received senior high school education. Her husband is a trader.

Evelyn has been selling feeding bottles and nursing equipment since 1999 and is responsible for paying school fees and bills. Her loan will be used to buy more babies' items like feeding bottles, nursing equipment and other items to expand her business. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save and to educate her children.

loans.use: To buy more babies' items like feeding bottles, nursing equipment and other items

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes M. sells kenkey at Atabadi near Elmina. Agnes has received senior high school education. She is married and has five dependents. Her husband is a blacksmith. Agnes has been selling kenkey since 1993. She is responsible for educating her children. Her loan will be used to buy more maize and other ingredients for the making of kenkey in large quantities for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to educate her children.

loans.use: To buy more maize and other ingredients for the making of kenkey in large quantities for sale

loans.name: Hugo Alberto

texts.es:
El señor Hugo Alberto no aparece en la fotografía en representación sale su esposa la señora María Guadalupe Bran Tovar.
Esta familia tiene un negocio de abarrotes desde hace 6 años llamado “Gaby”, con lo ingresos de este ellos pagan las colegiaturas de su hijo que esta en universidad privada  y las mensualidades son muy altas. Ellos quieren dejarle un buen estudio a sus hijos para que se defiendan en un futuro.
Pero el crédito es para surtirse de mercancía en este negocio, para mayor ganancias, aunque ellos trabajan en maquiladora los dos trabajan en horarios distintos para atender la tienda.
texts.en:
Hugo Alberto is not in the photograph. His wife, María Guadalupe Bran Tovar, is in the photograph representing him. This family has had a grocery business named Gaby for six years. They are paying the educational fees for their son with the income from the business. He is in a private university, and the monthly fees are very high. They want to give their children a good education so that they can take care of themselves in the future. The loan is to stock merchandise in their business in order to get more earnings. Both of them work in a factory. They work different shifts in order to take care of the store.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stock the business

loans.name: Joana

texts.en:
Joana Q. is married and has three children. She has received schooling through junior high school. Joana sells cosmetics, cloth, etc. in Elmina, which she has done since 2001. Her husband is a carpenter. Joana plans to reinvest in her business. Joana will use the loan to buy more and a variety of cosmetics and cloth to expand the business. With the new profits from her expanded business, Joana plans to save.

At the time the picture was taken, she was out of stock and had only a few items to show.

loans.use: To buy more and a variety of cosmetics and cloth to expand her business

loans.name: Luz Olivia

texts.en:
Luz engages in two different business ventures.  She has a fruit stand next to the lake of Yarinacocha, the small town where she lives.  Luz also purchases fish from small fishing communities along the Ucayali, a wide brown river that flows past the nearby city of Pucallpa and joins the Amazon to the north.  Luz takes several-day-long trips upriver with a cooler and a bunch of ice to keep the fish fresh.  Upon return she sells everything she has purchased at the port of Pucallpa.  Luz sets up her fruit stand during holiday periods and in the winter when the river is high and purchasing fish becomes more difficult.  

Luz has been working with Kiva partner Manuela Ramos for five years.  She hopes to invest this loan of 1000 soles in the purchase of more fish and fruits for her business ventures.  She will also save some of the loan to ensure that she can make all of her payments on time.    

Luz is 48 years old and is a single mother of three adult children (ages 25, 27 and 29).  Although all of her children live with her, none is still dependent on her.  Luz also has three grandchildren.  

According to Luz, things have gone very well for her working with Manuela Ramos.  Her credit has helped her a lot.  Her goal is to keep working and continue to expand her business ventures.  She hopes to someday purchase her own small passenger boat.  In this way, her son could have a job as its driver and Luz would not have to pay for her transport upriver on her fish-purchasing trips. 

Luz is pictured here at her fruit stand around the time of Peru's Independence Day holiday.  The lake of Yarinacocha is in the background.

loans.use: Fruits and fish for sale

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en: Samuel C., who has received senior high school education, sells soft drinks in Elmina. He is married to a trader and has two children. Responsible for paying school fees and bills, Samuel has been selling soft drinks since 1998.  His loan will be used to buy more soft drinks to increase sales and expand the business. He hopes to use the new profits from his business to complete a building project.

loans.use: To buy more soft drinks to increase sales and expand the business.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes D., who received no formal education, sells fish in Elmina. Divorced with eight dependents, she is responsible for paying school fees and other bills. Agnes has been selling fish since 1997, and her loan will be used to buy more fish for resale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business for savings and educating the children.

loans.use: Her loan will be used to buy more fish for resale.

loans.name: Adjoa

texts.en: Adjoa K., who received no formal education, has been selling fresh fish in Elmina since 1995. A single parent with seven dependents, Adjoa  is responsible for paying school fees and other bills. Her loan will be used to buy more fish for resale, and she hopes to use the new profits from her business for savings and educating her children.

loans.use: Her loan will be used to buy more fish for resale.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en: Beatrice Q., who received no formal education, is married with five dependents.  Beatrice sells fish in Elmina, a business she has operated for some time now. She uses her income to pay for school fees and other bills and will use the loan to purchase more fish for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Beatrice plans to save money and educate her children.

loans.use: Beatrice will use the loan to purchase more fish for resale.

loans.name: Ama

texts.en: Ama A., who received no formal education, is divorced and has three children. A fish seller in Elmina since 2001, she uses her income to pay for school fees and other bills. Ama will use the loan to purchase more fish for resale, and with the new profits from her expanded business, she plans to save money and educate her children.

loans.use: Ama will use the loan to purchase more fish for resale.

loans.name: Aba

texts.en: Aba A., who received no formal education, is a single parent with two children.  She has sold fish in Elmina  since 2001, using her income to pay for school fees and other bills. Aba will use the loan to purchase more fish for resale, and with the new profits from her expanded business, she plans to save money and educate her children.

loans.use: Aba will use the loan to purchase more fish for resale.

loans.name: Ama

texts.en: Ama G., who received primary education, has been selling smoked fish at Nyayeye near Elmina since 2001  A widow with three children, she is responsible for paying school fees and other bills. Ama's loan will be used to buy more fish for resale, and she hopes to use the new profits from her business to save money and educate her children.

loans.use: Her loan will be used to buy more fish for resale.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary A., who received no formal education, is divorced with four dependants. A fish seller at Nyayeye near Elmina  since 2001, Mary uses her income to pay for bills, and she will use the loan to increase her capital to buy more fish for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Mary plans to educate her children.

loans.use: Mary will use the loan to increase her capital to buy more fish for resale.

loans.name: Kate

texts.en: Kate A. sells smoked fish at Nyayeye, which she has done since 2006. She is a widow and has four dependants. She has received schooling through senior high school. Kate uses her income to pay for school fees and other bills. Kate will use this loan to purchase more fish for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Kate plans to save and educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase more fish for resale

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary D. is divorced and has 5 dependents. She has received no formal education. Mary sells fish at Nyayeye near Elmina, which she has done since 2004. Mary uses her income to pay bills. Mary will use the loan to buy more fish to increase sales and expand her business. With the new profits from her expanded business, Mary plans to educate her children.

loans.use: buy more fish to increase sales and expand her business

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en: Lucy S. is married and has two children. She has received schooling through junior high school. Lucy sells smoked fish at Nyayeye, which she has done since 2007. Her husband is a mason. Lucy uses her income to pay school fees and other bills. Lucy will use the loan to purchase more fish for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Lucy plans to save and educate her children.

loans.use: to purchase more fish for resale

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes B. sells bananas and bowls at Beposo near Shama. Agnes has received junior high school education. She is a single parent and has two children.

Agnes has been selling bananas and bowls since 2007. She is responsible for providing food for her family. Her loan will be used to expand her business by buying more and a variety of fruits and some other cooking utensils. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to pay her children’s school fees.

loans.use: buying more and a variety of fruits and some other cooking utensils for resale

loans.name: Llesica

texts.en:
Llesica is married and has two daughters, aged seven and four. She has been working with Kiva partner, Manuela Ramos, for eight years and has used her loans for a variety of different business ventures. Llesica's husband runs a vehicle repair shop and gets a lot of customers from a bus company located nearby. Llesica has helped him to expand and improve his shop.

Llesica also invests in raising and selling chickens. Currently she is trying to decide whether she should invest in raising chickens or turkeys for the upcoming Christmas season. While chickens are easier to raise, turkeys have the advantage of selling for a higher price.

Llesica also sells barbecued chicken and sodas and beer at the weekends. She can earn 160 PEN over the course of one weekend with this business. Finally, she used a previous loan to purchase a motorcycle taxi which she rents out for 20 PEN daily to a driver. She plans to use this loan of 2500 PEN to purchase another motorcycle taxi.

Llesica reports that her business ventures are doing well. Her goals are to expand her barbecue business, increase the size of her chicken coops in order to raise more chicks, and to eventually have a fixed business locale (such as a restaurant) that she can leave to her children. For this last goal, Llesica must first purchase a piece of land upon which to build her home. She and her family are currently living with her husband's parents.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle taxi

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth B. has a small grocery shop where she sells items such as fruit juice, tinned fish and the like at Beposo near Shama. Ruth has received junior high school education. She is married and has 6 dependents. Her husband is a farmer.

Ruth has been running the grocery shop since 2006. She is responsible for supporting her family. Her loan will be used to buy more provisions for resale to increase sales and expand the business. She hopes to use the new profits from her business for her children’s education.

loans.use: buy more provisions for resale to increase sales and expand the business

loans.name: Agatha

texts.en:
Agatha A. is married and has two children. She has received no formal education. Agatha sells traveling bags and pure water at Beposo near Shama, which she has done since 2005. Her husband makes sculptures.

Agatha assists in paying for the children’s education. Agatha will invest the new loan in the business by buying more and a variety of traveling bags and also mineral water for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Agatha plans to build a house.

loans.use: buying more and a variety of traveling bags and also mineral water for resale

loans.name: Kweku

texts.en:
Kweku A. has a small grocery shop at Beposo near Shama. Kweku has received junior high school education. He is married and has three children. His wife is a seamstress.

Kweku has been running the grocery shop since 2000. He is responsible for paying for his children's education. His loan will be used to buy more groceries for sale to increase sales and expand the business. He hopes to use the new profits from his business to build a house.

loans.use: to buy more groceries for sale to increase sales and expand the business

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en: Lydia A. is a widow and has 4 dependaents. She has received schooling through junior high school. Lydia sells plastic bowls at Beposo near Shama, which she has done since 2007. Lydia uses her income to educate her children. Lydia will use the loan to buy more bowls for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Lydia plans to build a house.

loans.use: to buy more bowls for resale.

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica J. sells onions and other spices at Beposo near Shama. Veronica has received junior high school education. She is married and has three children. Her husband is a commercial driver.

Veronica has been selling onions since 2004. She is responsible for buying food for the family. Her loan will be used to support the business by buying more food supplies for resale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to expand her business.

loans.use: to support the business by buying more food supplies for resale

loans.name: Philomena

texts.en:
Philomena B. sells bananas and bowls under a shed roof at Beposo near Shama. Philomena has received junior high school education. She is married and has 4 dependents. Her husband is a farmer.

Philomena has been selling bananas and bowls since 2006. She is responsible for buying food for her family. Her loan will be used to buy more fruit and cooking utensils and other goods for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest.

loans.use: to buy more fruits and cooking utensils and other goods for sale

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en: Theresa D., who received schooling through junior high school, is married and has four dependants. Since 2005, she has sold fish at Beposo, near Shama. Married to a city council officer, Theresa uses her income to pay school fees for their children, and with her loan, she will reinvest in her business by purchasing fish in large quantities for resale. Theresa plans to save the new profits from her expanded business.

loans.use: Theresa will reinvest in her business by buying fish in large quantities for resale.

loans.name: Francisca

texts.en:
Francisca has been working with Kiva partner, Manuela Ramos, for two years and is currently the official secretary of her communal bank, 'Teresa Ramos'. Francisca sells beauty products and also helps her father by investing in his business. Francisca's father purchases fruit and other crops from the small agricultural communities along the Ucayali, a wide brown river that flows past the city of Pucallpa and joins the Amazon to the north. He then resells the goods in the city.

Francisca used her very first loan of 300 PEN to begin her business selling beauty products. She plans to use this current loan of 1500 PEN in two ways. Some of it she will invest in more beauty products, and the rest she will use to help her father with his business.

Francisca is engaged and is due to have her first baby in December. Her partner works at the factory for Kola Real, a local soft drink. Francisca has many goals for the future. She wants to purchase a plot of land on which to build her own home as well as a store. She wants this store to either be a grocery shop or a small pharmacy. Francisca knows a little bit about medicine because she completed a course of studies to become a nurse technician. She hopes to return to school eventually to study pharmacy as well.

loans.use: To purchase beauty products and crops for resale

loans.name: Luis

texts.es:
El señor Luis M. tiene 55 años de edad, está casado con la señora Cristina. El mismo posee una parada de taxi propia donde trabaja como taxista hace 3 años aproximadamente, también realiza trabajos para varias municipalidades como contratista de obras hace 11 años.
Su esposa lo ayuda en los trabajos del hogar junto a una de sus hijas, en total tiene 4 hijos, 2 de los cuales viajaron hace varios años a España en busca de mejorar su calidad de vida, hoy en día los mismos consiguieron afirmarse logrando empleo y formar su propia familia en dicho país, mientras que el ultimo hijo lo ayuda en la parada de taxi cuando el señor Luis tiene trabajos que atender como contratista de obras. 
El préstamo que solicita es para reparar e innovar algunas partes descompuestas o viejas de su vehiculo que utiliza como taxi.
texts.en:
Sr. Luis M. is 55 years old and married to Sra. Cristina. He has operated his own taxi service for 3 years and also works as a contractor for several municipalities, which he has done for the past 11 years.

His wife and one of his daughters help with the housework. He has four children in total, two of which have traveled to Spain some time ago in search of a better life. Today, they have secured employment and started their own families abroad. Meanwhile, the youngest child helps with the taxi service whenever Sr. Luis is working on a contractor job.

The loan he is requesting will be used to pay for repairs on his taxi since some of the parts are old and have decomposed.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Vehicle repairs

loans.name: Maria Elisa

texts.es:
María, es una mujer dedicada al comercio, casada desde hace 22 años, madre de tres hijos, su esposo Ramón Veliz dedicado a la pesca en alta mar, oficio que lo  viene realizando desde hace algunos años y que requiere de mucho riesgo.
Ella cuenta con una pequeña  tienda en su propia casa, tiene la venta de productos de primera necesidad como arroz, azúcar, aceite, sal, nos comentó que desde hace 5 Años empezó con algo pequeño, vendiendo bolos, caramelos, galletas, fue ahorrando hasta que  invirtió una cantidad de dinero para poder comprar otros productos.
María en lo actuales momento se siente muy bien con su tienda pero aspira poder crecer con su negocio quiere comprar vitrinas, un congelador y mas víveres, pero le falta un gran detalle el dinero, por ello decide solicitar un préstamo de $ 1100 dólares a la fundación ESPOIR  y una vez que lo reciba poder invertir  todo ese dinero en lo antes mencionado.
texts.en:
María, is a woman dedicated to business. She has been married for 22 years and is the mother of three children. Her husband, Ramón Veliz, works fishing on the high seas, a profession that he has been practicing for many years and that requires of a lot of risk. She relies on a small store in her own house, where she sells basic necessities such as rice, sugar, oil, and salt. She commented to us that she began 5 years ago in a somewhat small way, selling candies, caramels, and cookies. She was saving until she could invest enough money to be able to buy other products. At present María feels very good about her store, but she aspires to be able to grow her business. She wants to buy showcases, a freezer and more provisions, but lacks a great detail: the money. Because of this she decided to request a loan of $ 1100 dollars from the foundation ESPOIR and, once she receives it she will be able to invest all that money in the items mentioned previously.

Translated from Spanish by Barbara (B) Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy showcases, a freezer and more provisions for her store.

loans.name: Clara Aurora

texts.es:
Scarlet de 3 años y Josue de 2 años son los hijos de Clara,  una joven madre de Milagro un cantón de la provincia del Guayas, en los actuales momentos radicada en la ciudad de Jipijapa.
Desde hace siete años formó su hogar, al principio vivieron en la ciudad de Guayaquil ya que es ahí que se conoce con su esposo, ellos trabajaban para una cadena de restaurantes ella en las ventas de comida china y el en una parrillada.
 Un año mas tarde deciden poner su propio negocio en Jipijapa y se radicaron desde hace seis años, el montó una cevicheria, luego de un tiempo pensaron en poner otro negocio pero sin dejar el actual.
Es entonces que Clara decide poner el negocio de venta de carnes, hígado, mondongo, pollo, desde hace 4 meses viene atendiendo desde muy temprano empieza su jornada 6: am hasta las 5: pm de lunes a sábados y los domingos de 5: am hasta las 5: pm. 
Comenta que no tiene nada de descanso ya que es ella la que se dedica de lleno al negocio puesto que su esposo tiene que  preparar  el pescado y atiende la cevicheria desde las 8: am el abre su local.
Clara comenta que gracias al apoyo de su suegra puede seguir adelante porque no es nada fácil poder enfrentarse a los desafíos de la vida, es que una de sus niñas nació con un problema de salud, y esta en terapias y han tenido que pasar por momentos muy difíciles tanto en lo económico como en lo emocional, ella se considera multifacética comenta, entre risa,  porque tiene que llevarse a sus niñas al local y ahí ha improvisado una cocina para prepararles los alimentos,  dice que se las tiene que arreglar de alguna manera, a sus 32 años Clara sueña con tener su propia casa algo pequeña pero de ella y de sus hijas, está solicitando un préstamo de $ 880 dólares  piensa en invertir en el negocio para hacerlo crecer.
texts.en:
Clara is the young mother of two children: Scarlet, who is 3, and Josue, who is 2. Clara is from Milagro, a zone in the province of Guayas, which lies in the municipality of Jipijapa. From the age of seven, this has been her home, although she first lived in the city of Guayaquil, where she met her husband. They both worked for restaurant chains: she worked in sales at a Chinese restaurant and he worked in a grillroom. After one year, they decided to establish their own business in Jipijapa, where it has been located now for six years. They first established a seafood restaurant, and later thought about constructing a second business. This is when Clara decided to begin a business of selling meats and meat products. For four months, she has begun her day very early, working from 6 a.m. until 5 p.m. from Monday through Saturday and from 5 a.m. until 5 p.m. on Sundays. She gets no rest, given that she is fully responsible for her business and her husband is occupied with the second business, preparing the fish and running the seafood restaurant from 8 a.m., when he opens for business. Clara notes that, thanks to the help of her mother-in-law, she is able to persevere, even though it is not always easy when faced by life's challlenges. One of her daughters was born with a health problem that requires therapy. This has resulted in both financial and emotional difficulties. Clara is considered multi-faceted, she says with a laugh, because she has to take her children to work and has had to improvise a kitchen there to prepare their meals. She says it must be done somehow! At her 32 years, Clara dreams of having her own house, something small but belonging to her and her children. She is seeking a loan for this reason and to invest in her business so that it can grow.

Translated from Spanish by Kara Gibson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy restaurant supplies.

loans.name: Ilda Alejandrina

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Campesinas de Ruizho esta ubicado en el sector de Ruizho, perteneciente a la comunidad de San Bartola  de Sigsig, se encuentra ubicada a una hora de la ciudad de Cuenca, su terreno es en su mayor parte accidentado.
Las principales producciones de la región son: maíz, fréjol, cebada, trigo, habas, arveja, patatas. En la parte baja se produce caña de azúcar y variedad de árboles frutales.
La parroquia se encuentra atravesada de norte a sur con yacimientos mineros de plata y hierro, existiendo también en la región sur criaderos de cal.
La principal industria es la agricultura, si bien muchos se dedican a la manufactura del tejido de sombreros de paja toquilla.
Este banco Comunal esta conformado por personas muy colaboradoras, organizadas y puntuales, el desarrollo de sus labores en el campo es la base fundamental para el compañerismo ya que cuando alguien necesita ayuda realizan mingas comunales, así también cuando hay festejos asisten todos.

Sra.  Ilda Alejandra Peñalosa U. tiene 45 años de edad, es casada, tiene 5 hijos, de 28, 18, 15, 12 y 6 años, es también responsable de 3 sobrinos menores de  10 años, cuenta que su hermana es madre soltera, menor que ella, tuvo tres hijos de diferente padres, hace tres años salio y hasta el día de hoy no regresa, Ilda se hace cargo del cuidado y manutención de los tres muchachos, dice que Dios le da fuerzas y paciencia para seguir adelante, y que nunca le falta comida para sus chicos, cuenta que en el campo es más fácil vivir porque la misma tierra les da de comer. Sus tres hijos últimos estudian dos en el colegio de San Bartola y el otro en la escuela Ruizho, gracias a su esposo que le ayuda trabajando porque tiene conocimientos de veterinaria ha podido salir adelante, el pasa trabajando en los lugares aledaños de Ruizho, en especial en haciendas que necesitan veterinario, Ilda vive en casa propia pero es pequeña de adobe y teja, a más de atender a su hogar y cuidar sus animales se dedica a trabajar vendiendo comida en el CREA y el parque el paraíso, lugares comerciales de Cuenca los días Sábados y Domingos, pero en el caso del CREA Ilda tiene que ir a dormir en un cuartito que arrienda por el mercado 27 de febrero de Cuenca porque su trabajo comienza desde las 3 de la mañana y termina a las 12 del día, y los Domingos de 6 a 2 de la Tarde, ella cocina cafés, chocolates, empanadas, secos, tortillas de maíz, tortillas de choclo, y otros alimentos.
El crédito que solicitó Ilda es de 550 dólares los cuales los invertirá comprando abono para su terreno, pollos de cría y mesas plásticas con silletas para su negocio, así también una cocina para el local, su meta es poder seguirles dando el estudio a sus hijos y construir una casa más segura y grande para toda su familia.
texts.en:
The “Campesinas de Ruizho” cooperative bank is located in the Ruizho sector, in the San Bartola de Sigsig community, an hour from the city of Cuenca. The primary crops of the region are: corn, beans, barley, wheat, peas and potatoes. In the lower areas, sugar cane and a variety of fruit trees are grown. The district is bordered on the northern and southern sides by silver and iron mines, and the southern area also has lime. Agriculture is the primary industry, and many people also dedicate themselves to making straw hats. This cooperative bank is comprised of members that are very collaborative, organized, and timely. Carrying out farming endeavors is the fundamental basis for their companionship given that, whenever someone needs help, they group together to help out. They also work as a group when there are celebrations and festivals. Ilda Alejandra Peñalosa U. is 45 years old, married, and has 5 children ages 28, 18, 15, 12 and 6. She is also responsible for 3 young nieces and nephews, all under the age of 10. She tells us that her younger sister, a single mother, left three years ago and never returned. Ilda took charge of caring for her children, and says that God gives her the strength and patience she needs to forge ahead. They are never lacking in food, given that the very land they live on provides sustenance. Two of her three oldest children study at the school in San Bartola, and the other at the school in Ruizho. Thanks to her husband’s help, who has veterinary skills, they have been able to get ahead. He works in the areas surrounding Ruizho, particularly the towns that need veterinary help. Ilda lives in a house they own, but it is small and made of adobe and tile. In addition to tending to the home and raising her animals, she works selling food at the CREA and the Paradise Park, commercial areas of Cuenca, on Saturdays and Sundays. In the case of her work for CREA, she has to sleep in a small room she rents near the 27th of February Market because she starts work at 3 am and finishes at noon. On Sundays, she works from 6 am to 2 pm. She makes coffee, chocolates, empanadas, corn tortillas and other foods. The loan of $550 USD requested by Ilda will be used to invest in the purchase of fertilizer for her land, poultry to raise, and plastic tables and chairs for her business. Her goal is to continue to provide an education for her children and to build a stronger and bigger house for her family.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer for her land, chickens to raise, plastic tables and chairs, and a stove for her food preparation business.

loans.name: Miriam Carmita

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Campesinas de Ruizho esta ubicado en el sector de Ruizho, perteneciente a la comunidad de San Bartola  de Sigsig, se encuentra ubicada a una hora de la ciudad de Cuenca, su terreno es en su mayor parte accidentado.
Las principales producciones de la región son: maíz, fréjol, cebada, trigo, habas, arveja, patatas. En la parte baja se produce caña de azúcar y variedad de árboles frutales.
La parroquia se encuentra atravesada de norte a sur con yacimientos mineros de plata y hierro, existiendo también en la región sur criaderos de cal.
La principal industria es la agricultura, si bien muchos se dedican a la manufactura del tejido de sombreros de paja toquilla.
Este banco Comunal esta conformado por personas muy colaboradoras, organizadas y puntuales, el desarrollo de sus labores en el campo es la base fundamental para el compañerismo ya que cuando alguien necesita ayuda realizan mingas comunales, así también cuando hay festejos asisten todos.

Sra. Miriam Carmita Peñalosa C. es oriunda de Ruizho, tiene 24 años de edad, vive en unión libre con Jorge Suqui (Albañil), dice que para ella no es necesario casarse, porque cuando ella quiere se separa y punto y no tiene problemas con nadie, tiene 2 hijos fruto de su relación, son de 8 y 6 años, estudian en la escuela Ruizho de la comunidad, su relación es de 8 años y es muy feliz, Miriam se dedica a muchas labores como son el cuidado de sus hijos, la crianza de animales,  en el campo y la panadería.
En los últimos tiempos se ha dedicado más a la panadería, esta profesión aprendió con gestiones del gobierno con las comunidades, la institución que promovió esta profesión fue el SECAP (Centro de capacitación profesional), ya lleva dos años haciendo pan dice que hace según los pedidos que tenga, por lo general son 100- 200 diarios, ella entrega a 0.08 centavos de dólar para que los de la tienda vendan a 0.10 o hasta 0.12 centavos al público. 
El crédito que solicitó fue de 330 dólares los cuales va a invertir comprando vacas lecheras para complementar vendiendo el pan con leche, la meta que tiene en el futuro es poder hacerse una panadera grande y poder extenderse hacia las comunidades aledañas.
texts.en:
The communal bank “Campesinas de Ruizho” is located in the area of Ruizho, which is part of the San Bartola de Sigsig community, located one hour outside of the city of Cuenca. The majority of the area consists of rugged terrain. The main crops grown in this region are maize, beans, barley, wheat, beans, peas, and potatoes. In the lower parts, you can find sugar cane and a variety of fruit trees. Mineral deposits of silver and iron crisscross the parish from north to south, and limestone formations also exist in the region. The main industry is agriculture, although many residents engage in making woven straw hats and shawls.

“Campesinas de Ruizho” is comprised of individuals who are highly collaborative, organized and punctual. The development of their rural businesses is the common bond that brings them together. Whenever anyone needs help with a particular project, they work together as a group (in community events known as “mingas”), and celebrate together afterwards.

Sra. Miriam Carmita Peñalosa C. is a native of Ruizho. She is 24 years old and lives in a common law relationship with Jorge Suqui (who is a mason). She says she doesn’t want to get married in order to avoid problems in case she decides to separate at any point. Two children (ages 8 and 6) have resulted from her relationship. They attend the community school in Ruizho. Miriam and Jorge have been together 8 years and are very happy. She dedicates most of her time to taking care of her children, raising animals, working on her farm, and operating a bakery.

Lately, she has spent more time working in her bakery. She learned the profession through a government arrangement with local communities. The institution that administers this program is called SECAP (Center for Vocational Training). In this two year program, students learn to make bread according to customer orders, usually producing 100-200 loaves each day. The bread is sold to stores for $0.08 USD each, which is then marked up to $0.10-0.12 USD when sold to the public.

Miriam is requesting $330 to buy dairy cows so that she can supplement her income by selling milk. Her goal for the future is to become a great baker and expand her business into the surrounding communities.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase dairy cows to supplement her income from selling bread

loans.name: Los Hijos De Dios Group

texts.es:
El anhelo más granD. D. la Sra. Juana Rosa es la  construir su casa D. material noble y abrir una bodega surtida donD. pueda generar ingresos para su familia y así mismo poder dedicarles más tiempo a sus dos hijos.
La Sra. Juana Rosa es una entusiasta mujer que a punta D. esfuerzo ha logrado adquirir un terreno, comprar sus artefactos y como ella dice “darle una mejor calidad D. vida a mis niños”. 
Ella se dedica a la venta D. ropa y cosméticos desD. hace 8 años, comenzando motivada por el impulso D. darle lo mejor a su primer hijo, cuando este aún era pequeño y ella percibía que los ingresos D. su esposo no eran suficientes para los tres. Además ella también trabaja en una fábrica desD. hace un año.
La Sra. Juana Rosa empezó con el grupo “Los Hijos D. Dios” hace tres años, y desD. hace cuatro meses presiD. la directiva, elegida D. entre sus compañeras por su sobresaliente carácter ante las adversidades. 
Gracias a Edaprospo-Prosperidad ella pueD. surtir su negocio en las épocas D. mayor demanda y atender sin problemas sus pedidos.
texts.en:
Juana Rosa’s greatest wish is to build her house out of sturdy materials, and open a well-stocked store where she can generate income for her family that would also allow her to spend more time with her two children. Juana Rosa is an enthusiastic lady who, through much effort, has managed to acquire some land, buy her artifacts, and, as she states, “proviD. a higher standard of living for my family”. She has dedicated herself to selling clothing and cosmetics for 8 years, having been motivated originally by her desire to proviD. for her first son. She perceived that her husband’s income was not enough for the three of them. In addition, she has also been working at a factory for a year. Juana Rosa started with the group “Children of God” three years ago, and for the past four months has presided over the board, having been elected by her colleagues for her ability to overcome adversity. Thanks to Edaprospo-Prosperidad, she is able to supply her business during the busiest seasons and fill her orders without a problem.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase polo shirts, sweaters, scarves, and also seasonal clothing to supply her store.

loans.name: Cruz Vicente

texts.es: Don Cruz Vicente B. T. Cuanta con 64 años de edad casado vive conjuntamente con sus 4 hijos es actualmente su dirección es 8 Avenida D-27 Zona 1 del municipio y departamento de Totonicapán Guatemala, se dedica al comercio  en venta de productos de alfarería donde comercializa fuera de la ciudad donde reside debido al poco capital de trabajo que tiene, sus clientes han aumentado debido al crecimiento que ha obtenido se acercó a la Asociación ASDIR para Solicitar un préstamo para poder cubrir la demanda de sus clientes que va en aumento ya que el producto que tiene es muy bueno por tal razón necesita mejorar su calidad de mercadería y así con la ampliación de su negocio pueda adquirir más clientes, y entregar calidad de su producto a su clientela.
texts.en:
Cruz Vicente B. T. Cuanta, 64 years of age and married, lives with his wife and 4 children in Totonicapán, Guatemala. He dedicates himself to commerce, selling pottery products that he markets outside the city where he lives. He has used the small amount of working capital he has to expand his customer base. Given the growth he has managed to obtain, he approached the ASDIR Association to solicit a loan to help him meet his customers’ demand. It continues to grow, as he has a good product, and he needs to further improve the quality of his merchandise. By expanding, he can attract more clientele and provide them with a quality product.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital.

loans.name: Chivarretense Group

texts.es:
Son un grupo de señoras organizadas en el año 2008 actualmente se dedican a diferentes actividades economicas tales como; comercio (compra y venta de ropa, zapatos entre otros), así también la crianza de
animales (gallinas, cerdos, vacas ovejas etc.), y servicio (promotores, trabajos en el campo,lavanderia entre otros), en el caso de las personas que se dedican al servicio tienen una actividad economica secundaria como lo es la crianza de animales el cual desean fortalecer para mejorar sus ingresos económicos y en el caso de las otras dos actividades su intención es diversificar su productos para mejorar los ingresos que actualmente tienen, y se ha determinado que todas ellas cuentan con actividad  económica para solventar su préstamo.
texts.en:
They are a group of women who organized in 2008. They currently work at different economic activities such as commerce (buying and selling clothes, shoes, and other things), raising animals (hens, pigs, cows, sheep, etc.), and services (construction, field work, and laundry, among others). The people who provide services have secondary activities like raising animals. They do this to improve their income. The intention of the other two activities is to diversify their products to improve the incomes that they currently have. It has been determined that all of them are engaged in economic activities that will enable them to pay back the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Isidoro

texts.es:
El señor Isidoro tiene 56 años de edad, vive acompañado de la señora Irma, tienen 5 hijos de los cuales solo uno vive con ellos, los demás ya son independientes y ya tienen su propia familia formada. 

Esta pareja tiene una despensa hace más de 24 años en su domicilio particular ubicada a escasa distancia del centro de la ciudad de Itá, allí surten a sus vecinos y a ocasionales clientes de todo tipo de insumos de primera necesidad como ser carne, panificados, verduras, lácteos, bebidas en general y otros productos.
 En muchas ocasiones compran tales mercaderías con la ayuda de los préstamos que adquieren de la Fundación Paraguaya. La señora Irma manifiesta que se siente muy en deuda con la institución ya que gracias al apoyo económico que recibió de la misma logró aumentar sus ingresos familiares y mejorar de esa manera su nivel de vida.
En esta oportunidad recurre nuevamente a la institución para solicitar un préstamo con el cual surtir su despensa con mercaderías tales como: carne, leche, panificados, bebidas, etc.
texts.en:
Sr. Isidoro is 56 years old and lives with Sra. Irma. They have five children, of whom only one lives with them. The others are independent and have families of their own.

The couple operates a 24 hour grocery store from their home, which is located a short distance from the city of Itá. They supply their neighbors and the occasional one-time customers with all types of basic necessities such as meat, baked goods, vegetables, dairy products, beverages, and other products.

As they have done many times before, they buy their merchandise with the help of loans from Fundación Paraguaya. Sra. Irma says she is indebted to the institution and is thankful for the financial support they have received. They have managed to increase their family income and thereby improve their standard of living. They have approached the institution again with a new loan request to purchase goods such as meat, milk, baked goods, beverages, etc.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase meat, milk, baked goods, beverages, etc.

loans.name: Eugenia

texts.es:
Eugenia de 47 años de edad vive en concubinato hace más de 18 años con  Rubén, de 60 años. Ambos han criado a 2 hijos  que hoy tienen 20 y 16 años respectivamente y  aún viven con ellos. 

Eugenia comenta que en su niñez tuvo que trabajar como niñera en una casa de familia y no pudo terminar sus estudios debido que eran muy humildes. 

Luego de conocer a su pareja decidió irse a  vivir en la Villa Conavi de la ciudad de Itá y tal es así que montóuna despensa que hasta hoy día funciona en su domicilio, además comenta que poseen muy buena clientela y que el negocio va en aumento.

Gracias a su  esfuerzo y sacrificio y a la ayuda de su marido pudo hacer estudiar a sus hijos, además de poseer ya su vivienda propia entre otras cosas para su comodidad. 

En esta ocasión solicita un préstamo para la compra de más mercaderías como: azúcar, harina, aceite, fideos, panificados, etc. de manera a poder surtir mejor su despensa y así poder ofrecer mayor variedad y calidad a su clientela.
texts.en:
Eugenia is 47 years old and has been living with Reuben, her partner of 18 years, who is 60 years old. They have raised two children, ages 20 and 16 respectively, who still live with them.

Eugenia says that in her childhood she had to work as a nanny for a family and could not complete her studies because her parents were of humble means.

After meeting her partner, she decided to go and live in Villa Conavi, which is in the city of Itá. From there, she started a grocery store from her home. She says she has a good client base and that her business is growing.

Thanks to her effort and the sacrifice and help of her partner, she was able to educate their children. They also own a house among the many things that make them comfortable.

This time Eugenia is requesting a loan to buy more merchandise such as sugar, flour, oil, pasta, baked goods, etc. She will be able to restock her grocery store and offer a greater variety and higher quality of products to her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase rice, flour, sugar, baked goods, pasta, etc.

loans.name: Juana Francisca

texts.es: Doña Juana Francisca T. T. Cuanta con 56 años de edad Viuda vive conjuntamente con sus 2 hijas actualmente su dirección es el Paraje Xejuyup, del Cantón Paqui  municipio y departamento de Totonicapán Guatemala, se dedica a la artesanía en la elaboración de muebles tiene un pequeño taller donde ella es la administradora y trabaja conjuntamente con sus dos hijas el cual la demanda de sus clientes son varios por tal razón acudió a la instalación de la Asociación ASDIR para adquirir un préstamo para utilizar  en la compra de materia prima y así crear otras fuentes de trabajo en su comunidad como también cubrir la demanda de su cliente que tiene fuera de la ciudad sufragando sus gastos personales y la de su familia dándoles una mejor vida.
texts.en:
Doña Juana Francisca T. T. Cuanta is 56, is a widow, and lives with her 2 daughters. She lives in Xejuyup in the area of Paqui, in the city and department of Totonicapán in Guatemala. She makes furniture in a small workshop where she is the manager and works together with her two daughters. She has turned to ASDIR to obtain a loan to meet the demand of her customers. She will use it to buy supplies and to create sources of jobs in her community so she can cover the demand of her customers that she has outside of the city. She will defray her personal expenses and those of her family so she can give them a better life.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Artisanship (to purchase supplies)

loans.name: Tomasa

texts.es: Doña Tomasa O. V. cuenta con 48 años de edad Casada vive con sus 4 hijos, actualmente se dedica a la elaboración de cortes típicos lleva 10 años dedicándose  a este oficio también vende este producto a diferentes clientes que ella tiene, cuenta con un  pequeño taller con operarios que trabajan para ella  según las exigencias y variedades de sus clientes han ido en aumentado y acudio a las oficinas de la asociación ASDIR para acreditar un préstamo para la compra de materia prima que ella utiliza en su trabajo facilitando a otras personas la demanda, como también mejorar sus ingresos y así poder sufragara sus gastos personales obteniendo mejores ganancias de su trabajo.
texts.en:
Doña Tomasa O. V. is 48, is married, and has 4 children. She has made traditional suits for 10 years. She sells these products to various customers that she has. She has a small workshop with employees who work for her. As the demand from her customers has increased, they have expanded and turned to the offices of ASDIR to receive a loan to purchase supplies to use in their work. She would like to increase her income to be able to defray personal expenses and to make more profits.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Artisanship

loans.name: Tzanjuyup Group

texts.es: Son un grupo de personas de 9 integrantes entre ellas hay hombres, se encuentran ubicadas a 21 kilometro de la ciudad, Las personas solicitantes del credito actualmente se dedican a difierentes actividades economicas tales como; comercio (compra y venta de delantales), así también a la crianza de animales (gallinas, cerdos, vacas ovejas etc.), y servicio (trabajos domesticos en hogares de forma mensual y trabajos agricolas en el campo entre otros), todos los miembros han demostrado de manera clara que cuentan con una actividad economica que garantiza el retorno del capital que se les esta otorgando, y dicho prestamo permitira ampliar su generación de ingresos familiares.
texts.en:
This is a group of nine people, including men. They are located 21 kilometers from the city. They are requesting a loan for their different economic activities such as buying and selling aprons, raising animals (hens, pigs, cows, sheep, etc.) and services (domestic jobs, agricultural work, etc.). All of the members have demonstrated in a clear manner that they have an economic activity that guarantees the return of the capital that is being offered to them. This loan will let them increase their generation of income for their families.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase their capital

loans.name: Las Afortunadas Group

texts.en:
The communal bank "Las Afortunadas" (The Fortunate Ones) was founded about four months ago. Most of the group's members live in a neighborhood called "26 de Marzo" (26th of March) in the city of Pucallpa. The bank's president is Teresa R. C..

"Las Afortunadas" has 11 members, three of whom are new this loan cycle. For most members, this loan will be their second from Kiva partner Manuela Ramos. The bank's members are requesting a total of 4,400 soles, which each member will invest in her respective business. The women of "Las Afortunadas" dedicate themselves to a variety of business ventures, including the sale of charcoal, clothing, soft drinks, cooked food and fruits. Several of the women work as seamstresses.

The members of "Las Afortunadas" are grateful to Manuela Ramos for the financial support they are receiving. They also appreciate the business education sessions given by Manuela Ramos loan officers at their communal bank's monthly meetings. The women are dedicated to progressing with their businesses.

loans.use: soft drinks, fruit, clothing, charcoal and other items for sale; materials for sewing work

loans.name: San Cayetano Group

texts.es:
El Comité de Mujeres de nombre San Cayetano, se conformó en fecha 20 de marzo del 2009, gracias a que la Directora General, la Sra. Basilia B. que se dedica a la venta de frutas, se informó del Programa gracias a la presidenta de otro grupo que era su vecina y la misma la invitó a formar su propio grupo, la misma contactó con la asesora informándose aun mas con respecto al programa y  de la forma de trabajo que tiene el Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras.
 Una vez asesorada acerca del Programa logró juntar a 17 mujeres quienes se encuentran trabajando muy a gusto ya pasando al 2do ciclo, en forma conjunta y solidaria dentro del programa.
El promedio de crédito retirado por cada integrante es de   429.411 Gs. lo cual va destinado para diferentes actividades tales como venta de bebidas, venta de carbón, venta de frutas, venta, venta de bijouterie, venta de medicamentos, venta de comestibles, etc.
Todas ellas realizan actividades para recaudar fondos, se ayudan mutuamente para llegar a los objetivos en común que todas tienen dentro del grupo y con la Fundación Paraguaya.
Participan activamente en las reuniones semanales y demuestran espíritu de trabajo en equipo.
Con el crédito comprarán: mercaderías para la despensa como arroz, azúcar, yerba, lácteos, panificados, gaseosas, etc. Compra de ingredientes para la elaboración de comestibles carne, harina, huevos, condimentos, etc., compra de carbón , bebidas, frutas, bijouterie, compra de CDs, medicamentos para  farmacia, compra de ropas, mercería en general.
texts.en:
The group of women called San Cayetano was formed on March 20, 2009, thanks to its general director, señora Basilia B., who sells fruits. She found out about the program thanks to the president of another group, who was her neighbor. She invited her to form her own group, and she contacted an advisor to get more information about the program and the work that Mujeres Emprendedoras does. Once she had all of the information, she succeeded in bringing together 17 working women, who are now on their second loan. They work together in a supportive manner. The average credit that will be loaned to each member is 429.41 guaranís, which will go towards different activities like selling beverages, charcoal, fruit, trinkets, medicine, food, etc. All of them carry out these activities to make money, and they help each other to reach their common objectives that they have with Fundación Paraguaya. They actively participate in their weekly meetings and demonstrate a spirit of teamwork. With this credit, they will buy merchandise for a grocery store like rice, sugar, mate, dairy products, bread, soft drinks, etc. They will also buy ingredients to prepare food like meat, flour, eggs, condiments, etc. And they will buy charcoal, beverages, fruit, trinkets, CDs, medicines, clothing, and general merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase rice, sugar, mate, dairy products, bread, soft drinks, meat, flour, eggs, condiments, charcoal, fruit, beverages, trinkets, medicine, clothing, etc.

loans.name: Valor Y Sacrificio Group

texts.es:
L. Sra. Leyli D. 31 años, es L. presidenta D. L. Alcancía Comunal “Valor y Sacrificio”, y aunque recién está integrando el grupo ha logrado ganarse L. confianza D. sus demás miembros.
L. Sra. Leyli es una mujer luchadora y trabajadora, y producto D. ese esfuerzo y sacrificio logró adquirir un vehículo el cual lo alquiL. para taxi desD. hace dos años, asegurando, D. esa manera, un ingreso diario para su familia. Su pareja fue quien L. convenció D. invertir en un auto, pues “un auto se paga solo” nos asegura elL..
ElL. vive junto a su conviviente y sus dos pequeños hijos que son su motor para seguir adelante a pesar D. los problemas.
ElL. aún continúa pagando las cuotas del carro, pero al ponerlo en alquiler elL. pueD. dedicar más horas a sus niños, y pueD. darles calidad D. tiempo que es lo que ellos necesitan para crecer firmes en una sociedad bastante difícil.
Dentro D. sus proyectos a futuro está el D. adquirir más unidades que le permitan mayores ingresos y con ello mejor calidad D. vida.
ElL. sabe que no será fácil, pero si empezar D. cero no fue imposible, alcanzar sus sueños tampoco lo serán.
texts.en:
Señora Leyli is 31 and is the president of the commual bank, "Valor y Sacrificio." Even though she just recently joined this group, she has succeeded in gaining the confidence of the other members. Leyli is a determined and hard-working woman. A product of this effort and sacrifice is the vehicle she was able to acquire, which she has rented out as a taxi for two years, which ensures a daily income for her family. Her husband convinced her to invest in a car because "a car pays for itself," she assures us. She lives with her husband and two small children, who are her motivation to get ahead despite any problems. She continues making payments on her car, but by renting it out, she can dedicate more time to her children and give them the quality time that they need to grow up strong in a rather difficult society. Among her projects for the future is to acquire more cars that will let her make a better income and have a better quality of life. She knows that it won't be easy, but if starting from nothing wasn't impossible, then reaching her dreams won't be either.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To maintain what they need for their jobs, whether it be cleaning, technical inspections, spare parts

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy peanuts to sell

loans.name: Mujeres Solidarias Group

texts.es:
El Comité de Mujeres de nombre Mujeres Solidarias, se conformo en fecha 13 de noviembre del 2006, gracias a que la anterior Directora General la Sra. Aída Luz R. quien se dedica a la venta de bijouterie, contactó con la asesora en una reunión semanal que la misma tenía en la zona, para enterarse de la forma de trabajo que tiene el Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras, una vez asesorada acerca del Programa logró juntar a 17 mujeres quienes se encuentran trabajando muy a gusto. 
El grupo en el transcurso de los ciclos, no tuvo inconvenientes   gracias a su trabajo solidario lograron salir adelante y seguir trabajando con el programa hasta estos días.
El promedio de crédito retirado por cada integrante es de   994.117 Gs., lo cual va destinado para diferentes actividades tales como venta de comidas, venta de mercerías, venta de mercaderías para la despensa, kiosco (arroz, azúcar, fideos, lácteos, panificados, yerba, etc.), venta de ropas, venta de frutas, venta de croché, venta de bijouterie etc.
Todas ellas realizan actividades para recaudar fondos, se ayudan mutuamente para llegar a los objetivos en común que todas tienen dentro del grupo y con la Fundación Paraguaya. Participan activamente en las reuniones semanales y tienen un trabajo solidario impecable.
texts.en:
The group Mujeres Solidarias (Women of Solidarity) was formed on Nov. 13, 2006, thanks to the work of former general director Aída Luz R., who makes a living selling jewelry. She contacted an adviser about having weekly meetings with working women from the area. Once she was told about the group loan program, she was able to bring together 17 women who take a lot of pleasure in their work. The group has not had any problems during the loan cycles thanks to the members working together to make headway, and they have continued working with the program to this day. The average loan per member is 994.117 Gs., which will be used for different activities such as selling foods, selling haberdashery, selling items for grocery stores and kiosks (rice, sugar, noodles, milk products, breads, etc.), selling clothing, selling fruit, selling crafts and selling jewelery. All the members carry our their work to repay the funds and they help each other to reach the common goals that everyone has within the group and Kiva partner Fundación Paraguaya. The members actively participate in their weekly meetings and have impeccable solidarity.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase ingredients and supplies for the members' respective activities

loans.name: Flor De Rosa Group

texts.es: Son un grupo de personas que integrann 8 mujeres y 2 hombres, ellas y ellos viven en ALDEA CHIVARRETO del departamento Totonicapán ellas se organizaron hace 6 meses para empezar un negocio conjuntamente con las 10 personas tratando que sus ventas lo realizan a cada mes en el mercado de San Francisco El Alto del mismo departamento que queda aproximadamente a 15 kilometros del lugar donde vivien,actualmente ellas se dedican a la Crianza de ganado porcino, Bovino, y crianza de pollos, asi mismo los dos hombres que integran el grupo se dedican al Comercio compra y venta de ropa, falda, camisas, etc, y las otras se dedican a la Artesanía  elaboracion de  faldas, camisas, las personas que crían los animales cuentan con 2 meses de engorde para venderlos en el mercado cercano, actualmente quieren incrementar sus capitales con la que cuentan, por esa razon acudieron a la Asociación para adquirir un préstamo de cada uno de ellas, pensando que con el tiempo que con la actividad que realizan les aumentará sus capital, como también sus ganancias mensuales, y de esa manera obtener mejores condiciones de vida para sus familias.
texts.en:
This group consists of eight women and two men who lives in the small village of Chivarreto, department of Totonicapán. The group was formed six months ago so the members could start working together to sell their products in the San Francisco El Alto market, located approximately 15 kilometers from where they live. Currently some of the female members make a living raising pig, cattle and chicken, while the two men work buying and selling clothing (skirts, shirts, etc.), which some of the other members make as part of their craftwork. For the members who raise the animals, it takes two months to fatten the livestock up to sell them at the nearby market. At present, the members want to increase their working capital, which is why they are turning to Kiva's partner to acquire a loan for them all to use. They think that with time their work will increase their profits as well as their monthly income, and in this way they can improve the quality of life for their families.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase working capital

loans.name: Ana Basilia

texts.es:
En el Mercado central de la ciudad de Chinandega, la señora Ana Basilia R. desde hace mucho tiempo se ha destacado por ser una excelente trabajadora por lo que vende sus artesanías de madera ofreciéndola a los clientes que le visitan a diario en el mercado.

Actualmente, ella ha buscado la manera de como surtir sus estantes con las artesanías de madera y para esto ha solicitado un crédito en Ceprodel para la compra de dichos productos y de esta menera comercializarlos en su localidad en el mercado. Actualmente ha realizado varios créditos con Ceprodel los que le han sido de mucho beneficio en su negocio.
texts.en:
Ana Basilia R. has worked in the central market of the city of Chinandega for a long time. She has stood out by being an excellent worker, offering her wooden craftwork to customers who visit her daily in the market. At present, she has looked for a way to increase her stock of crafts, and for this she has turned to Kiva partner Ceprodel for help purchasing said products and then selling them in the market. She has taken out a number of loans with Ceprodel that have been very beneficial to her business.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase wooden crafts

loans.name: Isidro Eradio

texts.es:
El señor Isidro P. ha unido sus esfuerzos para atender su negocio de ferretería en el mercado Central de la ciudad de Chinandega donde ofrece todo tipo de productos ferreteros los cuales son ofrecidos todos los días desde tempranas horas de la mañana.

La razón por la que ha solicitado el crédito es para la compra de los productos de ferretería ya que le es importante adquirirlos a lo inmediato por parte de sus proveedores para así satisfacer la demanda de sus clientes.
texts.en:
Isidro P. has centered all his efforts on tending to his hardware business in the city of Chinandega's central market, where he offers all kinds of hardware products every day starting at the early morning hours. The reason he is requesting this loan is so he can purchase his hardware supplies, since it's important he gets them immediately from his suppliers so he can satisfy his customers' demands.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase hardware supplies

loans.name: Reyna Francisca

texts.es:
El Mercado Central de la ciudad de Chinandega se caracteriza por tener mujeres muy esforzadas en su trabajo tale s el caso de la señora Reyna E. el cual vende verduras en las inmediaciones del mercado.

Ella se ha destacado por ser una excelente trabajadora y a pesar de la difícil situación económica que ha atravesado, ha logrado salir adelante en el negocio. La razón por la que ella acude a Ceprodel es para solicitar un crédito para la compra de las verduras y así comercializarlas en el mercado.
texts.en:
The city of Chinandega's central market is known for having very hardworking women, and such is the case for Reyna E., who sells vegetables in the market's surrounding areas. She has stood out by being an excellent worker, who despite her difficult economic situation has been able to make headway with her business. The reason she has turned to Kiva partner Ceprodel to request a loan is so she can purchase her vegetables and then sell them at the market.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase vegetables to sell

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.es: Cecilia es una mujer muy alegre, tiene 48 años, vive con su esposo Enrique y sus hijos: Joao de 19 y Gabriel de 15 años de edad. Desde hace 4 años se dedica a la venta de ceviche, (plato típico peruano elaborado a base de pescado y limón) en la parte de afuera de su casa. Este negocio surge gracias a que unas amigas que invitó a almorzar a su casa le dijeron que le salía muy rico este platillo y la alentaron a que saque beneficios. Es así que ahora tiene un negocio independiente al de su esposo y puede cooperar con los gastos del hogar. Cecilia ha sufrido mucha pena al perder a uno de sus hijos, pero su trabajo la ha animado para no darse por vencida por la depresión y seguir trabajando a favor de su familia. Para un futuro cercano espera tener un local donde venda su ceviche y pueda brindar una mejor comodidad a su clientela. Este es su tercer préstamo con MFP, en su grupo solidario siempre le ha ido muy bien, es por ello que se encuentra contenta con el progreso de todos sus compañeros. Con el dinero solicitado comprará mayor cantidad de pescado y algunas bancas extra para instalar a mayor cantidad de personas alrededor de su puesto.
texts.en:
Cecilia is a very happy woman. She is 48 years old and lives with her husband Enrique and their children; Joao is 19 and Gabriel is 15. For 4 years, she has sold ceviche (a traditional Peruvian dish made from fish and lemon) outside of her house. This business was started because she invited some friends to her house to have lunch and they said that this dish was delicious, and they encouraged her to pursue the business and earn the benefits from it. Because of this, she now has a business separate from that of her husband, and she can help with the household expenses. Cecilia has suffered a great deal because she lost one of her children, but her work has brought her to life by not allowing her to be conquered by depression and by allowing her to continue to work for her family. In the near future, she hopes to have a location where she can sell her ceviche and where she can offer more comfort to her clients. This is her third loan with MFP. In her solidary group, she has always done well. Because of this, she is happy with the progress of all of her peers. With the money that she is requesting, she will buy more fish and some extra benches to allow more people to be around her stand.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fish and benches for her stand

loans.name: María

texts.es: María tiene 50 años, vive con su esposo Francisco de 49 y sus hijos: Yoshabel de 22, Maife de 21, Joel de 18 y Milagros de 13 añitos; en su casa propia. Los últimos 12 años se viene dedicando a la venta de productos de belleza, pues ha sabido aprovechar la rentabilidad y ganancias que le da este negocio. María le dedica todo el día a su trabajo, después de dejar todo listo en su hogar, sale a ofrecer sus productos a las casas de vecinas y amigas, logrando convencerlas para que adquieran los perfumes, maquillaje, lápiz de labios y demás productos que ofrece vía catalogo. Ella se siente muy contenta, pues esta labor le permite tener libertad económica, además de conocer nuevas amistades. María está llena de esperanzas que la motivan, para un futuro cercano quiere tener un bazar donde pueda mostrar toda su mercadería y así obtener mejores ventas. Este es su tercer préstamo con MFP y siempre le ha ido muy bien en su grupo porque todas sus compañeras son muy responsables en los pagos. Con el dinero solicitado comprará mayor cantidad de cosméticos para incrementar su stock.
texts.en:
María is 50 years old and lives with her husband Francisco, who is 49 years old, and her children; Yoshabel is 22, Maife is 21, Joel is 18, and Milagros is 13 years old. She lives in her own house. For the last 12 years, she has sold beauty products, so she knows how to make the most of the profits and earnings that her business gives her. María spends all day working. After leaving everything ready in her house, she goes to offer her products at the homes of her neighbors and friends. She succeeds in convincing them to buy perfumes, make up, lip pencils, and other products that she offers through a catalogue. She feels very happy because this work allows her to have economic freedom and to make new friendships. María is full of hopes that motivate her. In the near future, she wants to have a bazaar where she can show all of her merchandise and, in this way, have more sales. This is her third loan with MFP, and she has always done well in her group because all of her peers are very responsible in their repayments. With the money that she is requesting, she will buy more cosmetics to increase her stock.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase her merchandise

loans.name: Ricardo

texts.es: Ricardo tiene 42 años, vive con su esposa Jeny y su pequeño hijo en su casa propia. Desde hace 4 años se dedica a la venta de mascotas en el Mercado Central de la ciudad de Lima, donde ofrece lindos perritos, hámster, gatos, tortugas, etc. Ella optó por este negocio porque siempre le gustaron mucho los animales y lo que más disfruta es pasar tiempo con ellos, es por eso que su trabajo no se le hace muy pesado; aunque la parte difícil radica en que algunas veces las mascotas adquieren alguna enfermedad y debe poner sumo cuidado en su atención. A Ricardo le hubiera gustado ser veterinario, pero ve en su trabajo lo que más se asemeja a ese sueño. Felizmente su esposa y su hijo comparten ese mismo amor por los animales, así que siempre trabajan juntos para de salir adelante. Este es su cuarto préstamo con MFP y siempre ha sido muy puntual en todos sus pagos. Con el dinero que ahora solicita comprará perros de raza Shitzú para criar y luego los venderá a un precio mayor.
texts.en:
Ricardo is 42 years old and lives with his wife Jeny and their young son in their own house. For 4 years, he has sold animals in the Central Market in the city of Lima, where he offers beautiful puppies, hamsters, cats, turtles, etc. He decided to pursue this business because he always liked animals. What he enjoys most is spending time with them. Because of this, his work doesn’t make him very tired. The difficult part of his business is that sometimes the animals become ill and he must take care of them. Ricardo would have liked to be a veterinarian, but his work is the most similar to this dream. Happily, his wife and son share his love for animals, so they always work together to go forward. This is his fourth loan with MFP, and he has been very punctual in all of his repayments. With the money that he is now requesting, he will buy Shitzu dogs to raise and, later, sell at a higher price.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase his merchandise

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Rina

texts.es: Rina tiene 48 años; vive con Carlos, su esposo, de 51 años y su hijo Kevin de 16 años. Se dedica a la venta de condimentos en el mercado Apecolit, que es uno de los más conocidos en el distrito de Comas, donde ella vive, a dos horas del centro de Lima. Heredó su puesto de su madre, quien anteriormente vendía carne, pero ella prefirió la venta de condimentos, los cuales son muy demandados, ya que es la única que vende estos productos en el sector de carnicería del mercado. A Rina le gusta mucho su trabajo, pues le da independencia y libertad económica, pudiendo así compartir los gastos con su esposo. Este es su tercer préstamo con MFP y siempre se ha caracterizado por cumplir puntualmente a la hora de pagar las cuotas. Con el dinero que ahora solicita comprará una malla para proteger su negocio cuando lo cierre, también adquirirá andamios para exponer mejor sus productos.
texts.en:
Rina is 48 years old; she lives with her husband Carlos, 51 years old, and her son Kevin, who is 16. She dedicates herself to selling condiments in the Apecolit market. It is one of the most well-known markets in the district of Comas, where she lives, which is about two hours from the city of Lima. She inherited her stand from her mother, who previously sold meats. However, Rina preferred to concentrate on condiment sales, which are in great demand as she is the only one that sells these products in the meat section of the market. Rina very much enjoys her work, as it allows her to be independent and financially free, as well as to share the household expenses with her husband. This is her third loan with MFP, and she has always characterized herself for her timely payments. With the funds she is now requesting, she would like to buy a screen to protect her business after she closes. She would also like to buy shelving to better display her products.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase materials to protect her products.

loans.name: Casilda

texts.es: Casilda tiene 29 años, vive con su esposo Eugenio, de 38 años, y sus hijos: Jocelyn de 14, Angélica de 11 y Diana de 5 añitos. Con el afán de proveer a su familia de una mejor calidad de vida, ha visto por conveniente dedicarse al negocio que comenzó su esposo, él es soldador de una fábrica pesquera y tuvo la idea de poner un negocio de fabricación de hornos; en el cual Casilda administra todos los ingresos y egresos, y compra los materiales necesarios para proveer a los trabajadores para la fabricación de hornos. Ella desea el progreso de su familia y esta actividad es una buena fuente de ingresos, además se siente independiente y útil para la sociedad. Para un futuro cercano quiere agrandar su fábrica, comprando más herramientas y contratando a más personas para también generar una fuente de empleo. Este es su primer préstamo en Microfinanzas PRISMA y espera trabajar muy bien con esta institución, comprometiéndose a ser muy puntual en todos sus pagos. Con el dinero solicitado comprará una máquina que le ayudará a elaborar sus hornos, Casilda considera que esta compra es el primer paso para la mejora de su negocio.
texts.en:
